Convergence of Random Variables

Modes of Convergence

  • A sequence of variables (Xn)(X_n)(Xn​) converges almost surely to XXX, written as Xn→X a.s.X_n\to X\text{ a.s.}Xn​→X a.s., ifP(Xn→X)≡P{ω:(Xn(ω))→X(ω)}=1\mathbb P(X_n\to X)\equiv\mathbb P\Big\{\omega:\big(X_n(\omega)\big)\to X(\omega)\Big\}=1P(Xn​→X)≡P{ω:(Xn​(ω))→X(ω)}=1where ω\omegaω is some event, and X(ω)X(\omega)X(ω) denotes the value XXX takes when ω\omegaω occurs.
    • that is, the times where the value of Xn↛XX_n\not\to XXn​→X are negligible (i.e. they form a null set), or Xn→X a.e.X_{n} \to X \,\mathrm{a.e.}Xn​→Xa.e. in the space of events.
  • (Xn)(X_n)(Xn​) converges in probability to XXX, written as XnundefinedPXX_n\xrightarrow{P}XXn​P​X, ifP(∣Xn−X∣<ϵ)→1, ∀ϵ>0\mathbb P(|X_n-X|<\epsilon)\to 1,\ \forall \epsilon>0P(∣Xn​−X∣<ϵ)→1, ∀ϵ>0
    • that is, each XnX_nXn​ is likely to be within a disk around XXX, but not necessarily likely enough to converge (it could pop outside every now and then)
  • (Xn)(X_n)(Xn​) converges in distribution to XXX, written as XnundefineddXX_n\xrightarrow{d}XXn​d​X, if ∀x where F continuous, Fn(x)→F(x)\forall x \text{ where } F\text{ continuous},\, F_n(x)\to F(x)∀x where F continuous,Fn​(x)→F(x)
    • that is, XnX_nXn​ will have a similar distribution to XXX, but they could be independent
    • there is no requirement at points where FFF is discontinuous

Descending Strength of Convergences

  • Convergence a.s  undefined(1) \,\xRightarrow{(1)}\,(1)​ convergence in probability  undefined(2) \,\xRightarrow{(2)}\,(2)​ convergence in distribution, while the converse is not true in general.
  • Proof of (1)(1)(1):

Define AN:{event ω:∀n≥N:∣Xn(ω)−X(ω)∣<ϵ}A_N:\{\text{event }\omega:\forall n\ge N:|X_n(\omega)-X(\omega)|<\epsilon\}AN​:{event ω:∀n≥N:∣Xn​(ω)−X(ω)∣<ϵ},
Then almost-sure convergence guarantees ANA_NAN​ occurs at least for some NNN, so P(⋃AN)=1\mathbb P(\bigcup A_N)=1P(⋃AN​)=1.
Since ANA_NAN​ is an increasing sequence of events, P(AN)→1\mathbb P(A_N)\to 1P(AN​)→1. ∗^{*}∗
Since ANA_NAN​ implies ∣Xn≥N−X∣<ϵ,|X_{n \ge N}-X|<\epsilon,∣Xn≥N​−X∣<ϵ, convergence in probability follows.

∗^{*}∗This is a standard result for P:F→R\mathbb{P}:\mathcal{F} \to \mathbb{R}P:F→R as a Lebesgue measure.

  • Counterexample of (1)(1)(1) converse:

Consider independent random variables XnX_nXn​ with distribution P(Xn=0)=n−1n,  P(Xn=1)=1n \mathbb{P}(X_{n}=0)=\frac{n-1}{n},\,\, \mathbb P(X_n=1)=\frac{1}{n} P(Xn​=0)=nn−1​,P(Xn​=1)=n1​
Then XnundefinedP0X_n\xrightarrow{P}0Xn​P​0, but P(∀n≥N:Xn=0)=0\mathbb P(\forall n\ge N: X_n=0)=0P(∀n≥N:Xn​=0)=0 for any NNN, so almost-sure convergence failes.

  • Proof of (2)(2)(2):

Since Xn<xX_n<xXn​<x implies X<x+ϵX<x+\epsilonX<x+ϵ or ∣X−Xn∣≥ϵ|X-X_n|\ge \epsilon∣X−Xn​∣≥ϵ for any positive ϵ,\epsilon,ϵ,
Fn(x)=P(Xn≤x)≤P[(X<x+ϵ) OR (∣X−Xn∣>ϵ)]≤P(X<x+ϵ)+P(∣X−Xn∣>ϵ)→F(x+ϵ)\begin{align*} F_n(x)&=\mathbb P(X_n\le x)\\ &\le\mathbb P\big[(X<x+\epsilon)\text{ OR }(|X-X_n|>\epsilon)\big]\\ &\le \mathbb P(X<x+\epsilon)+\mathbb P(|X-X_n |>\epsilon) \\&\to F(x+\epsilon)\end{align*}Fn​(x)​=P(Xn​≤x)≤P[(X<x+ϵ) OR (∣X−Xn​∣>ϵ)]≤P(X<x+ϵ)+P(∣X−Xn​∣>ϵ)→F(x+ϵ)​
Similar logic applied to 1−Fn(x)=P(Xn>x)1-F_n(x)=\mathbb P(X_n> x)1−Fn​(x)=P(Xn​>x) gives Fn(x)≥F(x−ϵ)F_{n}(x) \ge F(x-\epsilon)Fn​(x)≥F(x−ϵ).
Continuity of FFF at xxx makes F(x±ϵ)→F(x)F(x \pm \epsilon) \to F(x)F(x±ϵ)→F(x), so they sandwich Fn(x)→F(x)F_n(x)\to F(x)Fn​(x)→F(x).

  • Counterexample of (2)(2)(2) converse:

Let Y,X1,X2,…iid.Y,X_1, X_2,\dots iid.Y,X1​,X2​,…iid. (for example N(0,1)N(0,1)N(0,1)), then XnundefineddY,X_n\xrightarrow{d} Y,Xn​d​Y, but ↛Y\nrightarrow Y↛Y in probability.

  • Nevertheless, (2)(2)(2) converse is true if XnundefineddcX_{n} \xrightarrow{d} cXn​d​c constant–in that case XnundefinedpcX_{n} \xrightarrow{p}cXn​p​c.

Proof: fix any ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0. Then lim⁡n→∞P[∣Xn−c∣<ϵ]=lim⁡n→∞[Fn(c+ϵ)−Fn(c−ϵ)]=lim⁡n→∞[Fn(c+ϵ)]−lim⁡n→∞[Fn(c−ϵ)]=F(c+ϵ)−F(c−ϵ)=1\begin{align*} \lim_{ n \to \infty } \mathbb{P}[|X_{n}-c| < \epsilon]&= \lim_{ n \to \infty } \Big[F_{n}(c+\epsilon)-F_{n}(c-\epsilon)\Big]\\ &= \lim_{ n \to \infty } [F_{n}(c+\epsilon)] - \lim_{ n \to \infty } [F_{n}(c-\epsilon)]\\ &= F(c+\epsilon) - F(c-\epsilon)\\ &= 1 \end{align*}n→∞lim​P[∣Xn​−c∣<ϵ]​=n→∞lim​[Fn​(c+ϵ)−Fn​(c−ϵ)]=n→∞lim​[Fn​(c+ϵ)]−n→∞lim​[Fn​(c−ϵ)]=F(c+ϵ)−F(c−ϵ)=1​where the third equality uses Fn(c±ϵ)→F(c±ϵ)F_{n}(c \pm \epsilon) \to F(c \pm \epsilon)Fn​(c±ϵ)→F(c±ϵ); this is because FFF is continuous anywhere bar x=cx=cx=c, in particular c±ϵc \pm \epsilonc±ϵ.

Convergence Laws

  • the Strong Law of Large Numbers states that given random variables X1,⋯ ,nX_{1,\cdots, n}X1,⋯,n​ i.i.d. with mean μ\muμ, then their average Xˉ=∑Xn→μ a.s.\bar{X}=\frac{\sum X}{n}\to\mu\text{ a.s.}Xˉ=n∑X​→μ a.s..

Proof non-examinable.

  • the Central Limit Theorem states that under the same conditions as above, with σ2\sigma^2σ2 being the variance, there is: Xˉ−μσ/n=∑iXi−nμσnundefineddN(0,1)\frac{\bar{X}-\mu}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}}=\frac{\sum_{i} X_{i}-n\mu}{\sigma\sqrt{n}}\xrightarrow{d}N(0,1)σ/n​Xˉ−μ​=σn​∑i​Xi​−nμ​d​N(0,1)
    So roughly, Mn≈N(μ,σn)M_n \approx N(\mu, \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}})Mn​≈N(μ,n​σ​).

The proof is in the next section.

Generating Functions

  • As learned in Prelims, the probability generating function (pgf) of a variable X∈NX \in \mathbb{N}X∈N is GX(t)=E[tX]G_{X}(t)=\mathbb{E}[t^{X}]GX​(t)=E[tX]It is restricted to variables taking non-negative integer values, so we want something more general.

Moment Generating Function

  • the moment generating function (mgf) of a random variable XXX is MX(t)=E[etX]M_X(t)=\mathbb E[e^{tX}]MX​(t)=E[etX]
  • the Taylor series of the mgf “generates” the moment of the variable: with mk=E[Xk]m_k=\mathbb E[X^k]mk​=E[Xk] being the mmmth moment of XXX (about the point 000), MX(t)=∑k=0∞tkmkk!,M_X(t)=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \frac{t^km_k}{k!},MX​(t)=k=0∑∞​k!tkmk​​,
    • Hence MX(k)(0)=mk=E[Xk]M_X^{(k)}(0)=m_k=\mathbb E[X^k]MX(k)​(0)=mk​=E[Xk].
  • For the mgf to converge, XXX needs an exponentially decaying tail: the “tail” of its distribution that decays as fast as the exponential.
    • The normal and the poisson distributions have super-exponential tails (i.e. faster-than-exponential).
    • The exponential, geometric, and gamma distributions have exponential tails.
    • Distributions with polynomial tails do not decay fast enough, hence their mgfs might be undefined at places, if at all.

Using Moment Generating Functions

Big idea: mgfs determine the distribution, so combining variables is equivalent to combining their mgfs.

  • uniqueness: if X,YX,YX,Y have the same mgf, finite over some closed disk around 000, then they have the same distribution.
  • continuity: if (Yn):MYn→MY(Y_n):M_{Y_n}\to M_Y(Yn​):MYn​​→MY​, all finite over some closed disk around 000, then XnundefineddYX_n\xrightarrow{d}YXn​d​Y.

Both proofs are beyond the course so not examinable. Great.

  • Deriving the distirbution of combinations of random variables: for example given iid. X1,…,nX_{1,\dots,n}X1,…,n​, their sum YYY has mgf MY(t)=∏nMXn(t)M_Y(t)=\prod_n M_{X_n}(t)MY​(t)=n∏​MXn​​(t)If we can recognize MYM_{Y}MY​ as the mgf of some distribution DDD, uniqueness of mgf then determines Y∼DY \sim DY∼D.

  • Example: proof that independent variables X1∼N(μ1,σ12)X_{1}\sim N(\mu_{1},\sigma_{1}^{2})X1​∼N(μ1​,σ12​) and X2∼N(μ2,σ22)X_{2} \sim N(\mu_{2},\sigma_{2}^{2})X2​∼N(μ2​,σ22​) have the sum X1+X2=Y∼N(μ1+μ2,σ12+σ22)X_{1}+X_{2}=Y \sim N(\mu_{1}+\mu_{2},\sigma_{1}^{2}+\sigma_{2}^{2})X1​+X2​=Y∼N(μ1​+μ2​,σ12​+σ22​)

Proof: note that the standard normal has mgf et2/2e^{t^{2}/ 2}et2/2.
The mgf of XiX_{i}Xi​ is then Mi=exp⁡(μit+(σit)2/2)M_{i}=\exp(\mu_{i} t+(\sigma_{i} t)^{2} / 2)Mi​=exp(μi​t+(σi​t)2/2).
Their sum YYY has mgf MY=M1(t)M2(t)=exp⁡((μ1+μ2)t+(σ12+σ22)t22)\begin{align*} M_{Y}&= M_{1}(t)M_{2}(t)\\ &= \exp\left( (\mu_{1}+\mu_{2})t+\frac{(\sigma_{1}^{2}+\sigma_{2}^{2})t^{2}}{2} \right) \end{align*}MY​​=M1​(t)M2​(t)=exp((μ1​+μ2​)t+2(σ12​+σ22​)t2​)​which is the mgf of N(μ1+μ2,σ12+σ22)N(\mu_{1}+\mu_{2},\sigma_{1}^{2}+\sigma_{2}^{2})N(μ1​+μ2​,σ12​+σ22​). By the continuity property, Y∼N(μ1+μ2,σ12+σ22)Y \sim N(\mu_{1}+\mu_{2},\sigma_{1}^{2}+\sigma_{2}^{2})Y∼N(μ1​+μ2​,σ12​+σ22​).

  • Proof of the weak law of large numbers with mgf:

The average has mgf M∑X/n(t)=[MX(t/n)]n=(1+μtn+o(tn))n→etμM_{\sum X/n}(t)=\big[M_X(t/n)\big]^n=\big(1+\mu\frac{t}{n}+o(\frac{t}{n})\big)^n\to e^{t\mu}M∑X/n​(t)=[MX​(t/n)]n=(1+μnt​+o(nt​))n→etμThis is the mgf of the constant μ\muμ. By continuity ∑X/nundefineddμ\sum X/n\xrightarrow{d}\mu∑X/nd​μ.

  • Proof the CLT with mgf:

Define Yk=Xk−μY_k=X_k-\muYk​=Xk​−μ, with mgf MY(t)=1+σ22t2+o(t3)M_Y(t)=1+\frac{\sigma^2}{2}t^2 +o(t^3)MY​(t)=1+2σ2​t2+o(t3) near 000.
Then the variable (∑X−nμ)/(σn)(\sum X-n\mu)/(\sigma\sqrt{n})(∑X−nμ)/(σn​) has mgf Mn=(MY(tσn))n=(1+12nt2+o(t3n−3/2))n→exp⁡(t2/2),M_n=\Big(M_Y\big(\frac{t}{\sigma\sqrt n}\big)\Big)^n=\big(1+\frac{1}{2n}t^2+o(t^3n^{-3/2})\big)^n\to\exp(t^2/2),Mn​=(MY​(σn​t​))n=(1+2n1​t2+o(t3n−3/2))n→exp(t2/2), This is the mgf of N(0,1)N(0,1)N(0,1). Again by continuity, (∑X−nμ)/(σn)undefineddN(0,1)(\sum X-n\mu)/(\sigma\sqrt{n})\xrightarrow{d} N(0,1)(∑X−nμ)/(σn​)d​N(0,1).

  • Extra: given iid. random variables X1,X2,…X_{1},X_{2},\dotsX1​,X2​,…, and an integer-valued random variable NNN, with pgf GNG_{N}GN​, then the mgf of Y=X1+⋯+XNY=X_{1}+\dots+X_{N}Y=X1​+⋯+XN​ is MY(t)=GN(MXk(t))M_{Y}(t)=G_{N}\Big(M_{X_{k}}(t)\Big)MY​(t)=GN​(MXk​​(t))
    • This can be proved in a similar way as a similar result of pgfs in Prelims. For reference, it is Theorem 4.8\text{Theorem }4.8Theorem 4.8 on page 41 in the 2021 notes for Prelims probability.

Characteristic Function

  • The characteristic function of a random variable XXX is: ϕX(t)=E[eiXt]\phi_X(t)=\mathbb E[e^{iXt}]ϕX​(t)=E[eiXt]
    • that is, exit.
  • The characteristic function can be obtained by replacing ttt with ititit in mgfs (where they converge).
    • for example, the standard normal has mgf exp⁡(t22)\exp\left( \frac{t^2}{2} \right)exp(2t2​), hence a characteristic function of exp⁡(−t22)\exp\left( -\frac{t^2}{2} \right)exp(−2t2​).
  • Characteristic functions do not require exponentially decaying tails for convergence (unlike the mgf).

Joint Distributions

Recap: Definitions

  • The joint cumulative density function (cdf) of two random variables X,YX,YX,Y is FX,Y(x,y)=P(X≤x,Y≤y)F_{X,Y}(x,y)=\mathbb P(X\le x,Y\le y)FX,Y​(x,y)=P(X≤x,Y≤y)

  • The two variables are jointly continuous if this function can be written as a double integral: ∃f(x,y):F(x,y)=∫−∞y∫−∞xf(r,s) dr ds\exists f(x,y): F(x,y)=\int_{-\infty}^{y} \int_{-\infty}^{x} f(r,s)\,dr\,ds ∃f(x,y):F(x,y)=∫−∞y​∫−∞x​f(r,s)drdsand the function fff is the joint probability density function (pdf).

  • Given the joint pdf, A⊆R2A\subseteq \mathbb R^2A⊆R2, P((X,Y)∈A)=∬Af dA\mathbb P\big((X,Y)\in A\big)=\iint_{A}f \, dAP((X,Y)∈A)=∬A​fdA

  • The marginal distribution of XXX is obtained by integrating out YYY: fX(x)=∫−∞∞fX,Y(x,y) dyf_{X}( x)=\int_{-\infty}^\infty f_{X,Y}(x,y) \, dy fX​(x)=∫−∞∞​fX,Y​(x,y)dy

  • If variables X,YX,YX,Y are independent, fX,Y(x,y)=fX(x)fY(y)f_{X,Y}(x,y)=f_{X}(x)f_{Y}(y)fX,Y​(x,y)=fX​(x)fY​(y)Hence given independence, the marginal distribution can be found by factoring.

Conditional Densities

  • We can define the conditional cdf for an event AAA: FX∣A(x)=P(X≤x∩A)P(A)F_{X|A}(x)=\frac{\mathbb{P}(X\le x \cap A)}{\mathbb P(A)}FX∣A​(x)=P(A)P(X≤x∩A)​ and the conditional pdf fX∣A(x)f_{X|A}(x)fX∣A​(x) is its derivative.
  • Then the conditional probability and expectation areP(X∈C ∣ A)=∫CfX∣A(x) dxE(X∣A)=∫x⋅fX∣A(x) dx\begin{align*} \mathbb{P}(X\in C\,|\,A)&=\int_{C}f_{X|A}(x) \, dx\\ \mathbb{E}(X|A)&=\int x\cdot f_{X|A}(x) \, dx \end{align*}P(X∈C∣A)E(X∣A)​=∫C​fX∣A​(x)dx=∫x⋅fX∣A​(x)dx​ * The conditional density function of YYY given X=xX=xX=x is: fY∣X=x(y)=fX,YfXf_{Y|X=x}(y)=\frac{f_{X,Y}}{f_{X}}fY∣X=x​(y)=fX​fX,Y​​ for x:fX(x)≠0x:f_{X}(x)\ne 0x:fX​(x)=0.

Transformation Formula in 2D

  • For the entire section, we will be transforming from the random variables X,YX,YX,Y to the new variables T(x,y)=(U(x,y),V(x,y))T(x,y)=\big(U(x,y),V(x,y)\big)T(x,y)=(U(x,y),V(x,y)).

  • The transformation formula gives:
    Within the region T(R)T(R)T(R), RRR being the region where X,YX,YX,Y has non-000 distribution, fU,V(u,v)=fX,Y(x(u,v),y(u,v))∣det⁡∂(u,v)∂(x,y)∣f_{U,V}(u,v)=f_{X,Y}\Big(x(u,v),y(u,v)\Big)\Bigg|\det\frac{\partial(u,v)}{\partial(x,y)}\Bigg|fU,V​(u,v)=fX,Y​(x(u,v),y(u,v))∣∣​det∂(x,y)∂(u,v)​∣∣​where ∂(u,v)∂(x,y)\frac{\partial(u,v)}{\partial(x,y)}∂(x,y)∂(u,v)​ is the Jacobian (matrix) J=∂(u,v)∂(x,y)=(uxuyvxvy)J=\frac{\partial(u,v)}{\partial(x,y)}=\begin{pmatrix} u_{x} & u_{y} \\ v_{x} & v_{y} \end{pmatrix}J=∂(x,y)∂(u,v)​=(ux​vx​​uy​vy​​)and outside T(R)T(R)T(R), fU,V(u,v)=0f_{U,V}(u,v)=0fU,V​(u,v)=0.

Proof: for any A⊆RA\subseteq RA⊆R, there is T(A)⊆T(R)T(A)\subseteq T(R)T(A)⊆T(R), so we can write P((X,Y)∈A)=P((U,V)∈T(A))\mathbb P\big((X,Y)\in A\big)=\mathbb P\big((U,V)\in T(A)\big)P((X,Y)∈A)=P((U,V)∈T(A))as a double integral, and apply the change-of-variable theorm learned in Prelims multivariable calculus.

  • Example: deriving the distribution of the sum of two random variables.

Transform from (X,Y)(X,Y)(X,Y) to (X+Y,Y)(X+Y,Y)(X+Y,Y) with a Jacobian of determinant 111, and substitute XXX with X=(X+Y)−YX=(X+Y)-YX=(X+Y)−Y, we havefX+Y, Y(u,v)=fX,Y(u−v,v)⋅1f_{X+Y,\,Y}(u,v)=f_{X,Y}(u-v,v)\cdot 1fX+Y,Y​(u,v)=fX,Y​(u−v,v)⋅1so integrating gives the marginal distribution, fX+Y(u)=∫−∞∞fX,Y(u−v,v) dvf_{X+Y}(u)=\int _{-\infty}^\infty f_{X,Y}(u-v,v)\, dv fX+Y​(u)=∫−∞∞​fX,Y​(u−v,v)dv

Transformations and Gaussians in Higher Dimensions

  • The same formula holds for higher dimensions, where the Jacobian has the entries defined as (∂(x1,…,xn)∂(y1,…,yn))i,j=∂xi∂yj\Bigg( \frac{\partial(x_{1},\dots,x_{n})}{\partial(y_{1},\dots, y_{n})}\Bigg )_{i,j}=\frac{\partial x_{i}}{\partial y_{j}}(∂(y1​,…,yn​)∂(x1​,…,xn​)​)i,j​=∂yj​∂xi​​

  • For linear transformations W=AZ+μ\mathbf{W}=A\mathbf{Z}+\mathbf{\mu}W=AZ+μ, the Jacobian is just A−1A^{-1}A−1, hence fW(w)=fZ(z(w))∣det⁡A∣f_{\mathbf{W}}(\mathbf{w})=\frac{f_{\mathbf{Z}}(\mathbf{z}(\mathbf{w}))}{|\det A|}fW​(w)=∣detA∣fZ​(z(w))​

  • For example, given iid. standard normal variables Z\mathbf{Z}Z, the transformed W=AZ+μ‾\mathbf{W}=A\mathbf{Z}+\underline{\mu}W=AZ+μ​ would have distribution fW(w)=1(2π)n/2∣det⁡A∣exp⁡(−12(w−μ‾)T(AAT)−1(w−μ‾))f_{\mathbf{W}}(\mathbf{w})=\frac{1}{(2\pi)^{n/2}|\det A|}\exp\left( -\frac{1}{2}(\mathbf{ w-\underline{\mu}})^T(AA^T)^{-1}(\mathbf{ w-\underline{\mu}}) \right)fW​(w)=(2π)n/2∣detA∣1​exp(−21​(w−μ​)T(AAT)−1(w−μ​))(You probably don’t need to memorize this…) so they follow the multivariate normal distribution N(μ‾,AAT)N(\underline{\mu},A A^T)N(μ​,AAT), where AATA A^{T}AAT is the covariance matrix.

  • The covariance matrix of random variables X1,…,XnX_{1},\dots,X_{n}X1​,…,Xn​ is the matrix Σn×n\Sigma_{n\times n}Σn×n​ where (Σ)ij=Cov(Xi,Xj)(\Sigma)_{ij}=\mathrm{Cov}(X_{i},X_{j})(Σ)ij​=Cov(Xi​,Xj​)So independent variables have a diagonal covariance matrix. While the converse is not true in general, it does hold for Gaussians…

  • If the covariance matrix AAT=IA A^{T}=IAAT=I in the multivariate Gaussian W=(W1,…,Wn)\mathbf{W}=(W_{1},\dots,W_{n})W=(W1​,…,Wn​), then its pdf can be factored as fW=∏i=1nfwi(wi)f_{\mathbf{W}}=\prod_{i=1}^{n}f_{w_{i}}(w_{i})fW​=i=1∏n​fwi​​(wi​)So W1,…,WnW_{1},\dots,W_{n}W1​,…,Wn​ are indeed independent.

    • Here AAA is called “orthogonal”; a similar result holds for AAT=diag(… )AA^{T}=\mathrm{diag}(\dots)AAT=diag(…), but the algebra is even messier.

A Random Section on Constructing Normal Variables

  • Goal: construct two random normal variables X,YX,YX,Y following N(m,s)\mathcal{N}(m,s)N(m,s) and N(μ,σ)\mathcal{N}(\mu,\sigma)N(μ,σ) respectively, having a correlation of ρ\rhoρ

Idea: decompose YYY into a Z1Z_{1}Z1​ that it shares with XXX, plus an independent part Z2Z_{2}Z2​, with Z1,2Z_{1,2}Z1,2​ iid. N(0,1)\mathcal{N}(0,1)N(0,1).
The coefficient of Z1Z_{1}Z1​ would control the correlation, and we adjust the coefficient of Z2Z_{2}Z2​ to make sure the variance of YYY is correct.

  • Step 1: construct XXX with Z1Z_{1}Z1​.

To have X∼N(m,s),X\sim \mathcal{N}(m,s),X∼N(m,s), we just choose Z1∼N(0,1), X=sZ1+mZ_{1}\sim \mathcal{N}(0,1),\, X=sZ_{1}+mZ1​∼N(0,1),X=sZ1​+m.

  • Step 2: fit Z1Z_{1}Z1​ into YYY to get the correlation right.

We start with Y=σZ1+μY=\sigma Z_{1} +\muY=σZ1​+μ, but to fix the correlation,
observe that since Z1Z_{1}Z1​ independent from Z2Z_{2}Z2​ and μ\muμ,
corr(X,Y)=ρ=coeff(Z1)\text{corr}(X,Y)=\rho=\text{coeff}(Z_{1})corr(X,Y)=ρ=coeff(Z1​), so we can set Y=ρσZ1+μY=\rho \sigma Z_{1} +\muY=ρσZ1​+μ.

  • Step 3: add Z2Z_{2}Z2​ to fix the variance of YYY

We need σ\sigmaσ but we only have ρσ\rho \sigmaρσ, so add σ1−ρ2Z2\sigma\sqrt{1-\rho^{2}} Z_{2}σ1−ρ2​Z2​ (remember the coefficients are squared in computing the variance).
Again since Z1,2Z_{1,2}Z1,2​ independent, adding this term does not change the correlation.

  • So we have X=sZ1+mY=σρZ1+σ1−ρ2Z2+μwhere Z1,2∼N(0,1) iid.\begin{align*} X&=sZ_{1}+m\\ Y&= \sigma \rho Z_{1}+ \sigma \sqrt{ 1-\rho^{2 }Z_{2}} + \mu &&\text{where } Z_{1,2} \sim \mathcal{N}(0,1) \text{ iid.} \end{align*}XY​=sZ1​+m=σρZ1​+σ1−ρ2Z2​​+μ​​where Z1,2​∼N(0,1) iid.​which satisfies our conditions set in the goal.
  • Tying back to conditional distributions, we can write YYY in terms of XXX, which then gives the conditonal distribution of YYY given X=xX=xX=x.

Markov Chains - Introduction

Context

You can safely skip this section unless you have absolutely no idea about what Markov chains are.

  • Suppose we have a sequence of random variables (Xn)(X_{n})(Xn​) taking on values from a countable set III called the state space.
  • Usually the sequence is a change over time, e.g. the location of an elevator at time nnn, and the state space is the set of floors {1,2,…k}\{1,2,\dots k\}{1,2,…k}; or over a more abstract sense of time, e.g. the nnnth character in an email.
  • The distribution of some variable XnX_{n}Xn​ on state space III can be written as a row vector λn\lambda_{n}λn​, where (λn)i=P(X=Ii)(\lambda _{n})_{i}=\mathbb{P}(X=I_{i})(λn​)i​=P(X=Ii​).
    • In particular, λ0\lambda_{0}λ0​ is the initial distribution.

Definitions

Big idea: homogeneous Markove chains are memoriless random processes.

  • A sequence of random variables X=(X1,X2,… )X=(X_{1},X_{2},\dots)X=(X1​,X2​,…) all taking values in some state space III is called a Markov chain if for any k≥1k\ge 1k≥1, any states i0,…,ki_{0,\dots, k}i0,…,k​: P(Xk=ik∣Xk−1=ik−1)=P(Xk=ik∣Xk−1=ik−1,…,X1=i1)\mathbb{P}(X_{k}=i_{k}|X_{k-1}=i_{k-1})= \mathbb{P}(X_{k}=i_{k}|X_{k-1}=i_{k-1},\dots,X_{1}=i_{1})P(Xk​=ik​∣Xk−1​=ik−1​)=P(Xk​=ik​∣Xk−1​=ik−1​,…,X1​=i1​)

    • That is, the next state of the chain only depends on the present state, not the past.

  • A Markov chain is time-homogeneous if the probability P(Xk=j∣Xk−1=i)=pij\mathbb{P}(X_{k}=j|X_{k-1}=i)=p_{ij}P(Xk​=j∣Xk−1​=i)=pij​is constant, i.e. invariant of kkk. All chains in this course are homogeneous.

    • Hence pijp_{ij}pij​ is the probability of going from state iii to state jjj.

  • For homogeneous chains, the transition matrix P∈M∣I∣×∣I∣(R): Pi,j=pijP\in \mathcal{M}_{|I|\times|I|}(\mathbb{R}):\, P_{i,j}=p_{ij}P∈M∣I∣×∣I∣​(R):Pi,j​=pij​records the transition probabilities. The sequence XXX can be described as X∼Markov(λ0,P)X\sim \text{Markov}(\lambda_{0},P)X∼Markov(λ0​,P).

Properties

  • Homogeneous Markov chains satisfy the Markov property: for subsets A1,…m+n⊆I, i∈I,A_{1,\dots m+n}\subseteq I, \, i \in I,A1,…m+n​⊆I,i∈I,P(Xm+1∈Am+1,…,Xm+n∈Am+n∣Xm=i,Xm−1∈Am−1,…,X1∈A1)=P(Xm+1∈Am+1,…,Xm+n∈Am+n∣Xm=i)=P(X1∈A1,…,Xn∈An∣X0=i0)\begin{align*} \mathbb{P}(X_{m+1}\in A_{m+1},&\dots, X_{m+n}\in A_{m+n}|X_{m}=i, X_{m-1}\in A_{m-1},\dots, X_{1}\in A_{1})\\ \\ &=\mathbb{P}(X_{m+1}\in A_{m+1},\dots, X_{m+n}\in A_{m+n}|X_{m}=i) \\\\ &=\mathbb{P}(X_{1}\in A_{1},\dots, X_{n}\in A_{n}|X_{0}=i_{0}) \end{align*}P(Xm+1​∈Am+1​,​…,Xm+n​∈Am+n​∣Xm​=i,Xm−1​∈Am−1​,…,X1​∈A1​)=P(Xm+1​∈Am+1​,…,Xm+n​∈Am+n​∣Xm​=i)=P(X1​∈A1​,…,Xn​∈An​∣X0​=i0​)​
    • The first equality: Markov chains do not remember what happened before the present.
    • *The second equality: homogeneous Markov chains are translation-invariant.
  • A sufficient criterion for a Markov chain is that: a sequence of random variable Y=(Y0,… )Y=(Y_{0},\dots)Y=(Y0​,…) is a Markov chain if there exists a function fff and an sequence X=(X0,… )X=(X_{0},\dots)X=(X0​,…) such that: Yn+1=f(Yn,Xn+1), Xn+1 independent of Y1,…,nY_{n+1}=f(Y_{n},X_{n+1}),\, X_{n+1} \text{ independent of }Y_{1,\dots,n}Yn+1​=f(Yn​,Xn+1​),Xn+1​ independent of Y1,…,n​

N-Step Transition Probabilities

  • The nnn-step transition probability is defined to bepij(n)=P(Xn=j∣X0=i)p_{ij}^{(n)}=\mathbb{P}(X_{n}=j|X_{0}=i)pij(n)​=P(Xn​=j∣X0​=i)
  • The Chapman-Kolmogorov equations are satisfied by all homogeneous Markov chains: pij(m+n)=∑k∈Ipik(m)pkj(n)pij(n)=(Pn)ij\begin{align*} p_{ij}^{(m+n)}&=\sum_{k \in I} p_{ik}^{(m)} p_{kj}^{(n)}\\ p_{ij}^{(n)}&=(P^n)_{ij} \end{align*}pij(m+n)​pij(n)​​=k∈I∑​pik(m)​pkj(n)​=(Pn)ij​​
    • The first equation: probability of going from iii to jjj in m+nm+nm+n steps can be broken down by conditioning on it passing kkk at the mmmth step.
    • The second equation: right-applying the transition matrix represents a forward move in time. Hence for n≥m,n\ge m,n≥m,λn=λmPn−m\lambda_{n}=\lambda_{m}P^{n-m}λn​=λm​Pn−m

Proof:
First equation: use the law of total probability by conditioning on it passing kkk at the mmmth step.
Second equation: induction.

Structures of Markov Chains

Class Structures

  • Two states i,ji,ji,j of a Markov chain communicate, denoted i↔ji\leftrightarrow ji↔j if: ∃m,n:pij(m)≠0, pji(n)≠0\exists m,n:p_{ij}^{(m)}\ne 0,\, p_{ji}^{(n)}\ne 0∃m,n:pij(m)​=0,pji(n)​=0

    • That is, there is a chance to go from iii to jjj, and vice versa.

  • As an equivalence relation, communication partitions the state space into communicating classes.

  • A closed class CCC is a communicating class such that: ∀c∈C,d∉C,n∈N:  pcd(n)=0\forall c \in C, d \notin C, n\in \mathbb{N}:\, \,p_{cd}^{(n)}=0∀c∈C,d∈/C,n∈N:pcd(n)​=0

    • That is, it is impossible to leave CCC once inside it.

  • An absorbing state is a closed class with exactly one element.

  • An open state is a communicating class that is not closed.

  • A Markov chain is irreducible if it only has one communicating class.

Periodicity

  • The period of a state iii is gcd⁡{n:pii(n)>0}\gcd \big\{n:p_{ii}^{(n)}>0\big\}gcd{n:pii(n)​>0}and the state is aperiodic if its period is 111.

    • For example, a random walk of a length-nnn cycle has period 222 if nnn even; if nnn is odd, then the chain has period 111 hence is apeiodic.

  • The period is a class property: communicating states have the same period.

Proof: suppose i↔ji \leftrightarrow ji↔j, with m,n:pij(m)≠0, pji(n)≠0m,n: p_{ij}^{(m)}\ne 0,\, p_{ji}^{(n)}\ne 0m,n:pij(m)​=0,pji(n)​=0.
Define Si={n:pii(n)>0}S_{i}=\big\{n:p_{ii}^{(n)}>0\big\}Si​={n:pii(n)​>0}, similarly for SjS_{j}Sj​.
Then for any divisor ddd of SiS_{i}Si​,
pii(m+n)≥pij(m)pji(n)>0⟹(m+n)∈Si,d∣(m+n) p_{ii}^{(m+n)}\ge p_{ij}^{(m)}p_{ji}^{(n)}>0 \Longrightarrow (m+n) \in S_{i}, d|(m+n)pii(m+n)​≥pij(m)​pji(n)​>0⟹(m+n)∈Si​,d∣(m+n)and for any a∈Sja \in S_{j}a∈Sj​, pii(m+a+n)≥pij(m)pjj(a)pji(n)>0⟹(m+n+a)∈Si,d∣(m+n+a)p_{ii}^{(m+a+n)}\ge p_{ij}^{(m)}p_{jj}^{(a)}p_{ji}^{(n)}>0\Longrightarrow (m+n+a) \in S_{i}, d|(m+n+a)pii(m+a+n)​≥pij(m)​pjj(a)​pji(n)​>0⟹(m+n+a)∈Si​,d∣(m+n+a) Hence d∣ad|ad∣a, ddd is also a divisor of the set SjS_{j}Sj​,
By symmetry, Si,SjS_{i}, S_{j}Si​,Sj​ have the same divisors, hence the same gcd\mathrm{gcd}gcd, and so states i,ji,ji,j have the same period.

Hitting Probability

  • The hitting probability of a subset A⊆IA \subseteq IA⊆I from state iii ishiA=P(Xn∈A for some n ∣ X0=i)h_{i}^A=\mathbb{P}(X_{n} \in A \text{ for some }n\,|\, X_{0}=i)hiA​=P(Xn​∈A for some n∣X0​=i)and if AAA is closed, it is also called the absorption probability.

  • The hitting probabilities (i∈I:hiA)(i\in I:h_{i}^A)(i∈I:hiA​) of a Markov chain is the minimal non-negative solution to the equations hiA={1if i∈A∑j∈IpijhjAif i∉Ah_{i}^A=\begin{cases} 1 &\text{if }i\in A \\ \sum_{j\in I}p_{ij}h_{j}^A & \text{if } i\notin A \end{cases}hiA​={1∑j∈I​pij​hjA​​if i∈Aif i∈/A​where minimality means that (hiA)(h_{i}^A)(hiA​) is term-wise no larger than any other solution.

Proof: we can verify that (hiA)(h_{i}^A)(hiA​) satisfies the equations by conditioning on X0=i,X1=jX_{0}=i,X_{1}=jX0​=i,X1​=j.
To prove minimality, take any solution (xi)(x_{i})(xi​), and we shall show that ∀i∈I:xi≥hi\forall i \in I: x_{i}\ge h_{i}∀i∈I:xi​≥hi​.
Define the "probability of hitting before step NNN": qi(N)=P(∃n≤N:Xn∈A ∣ X0=i)q_{i}^{(N)}=\mathbb{P}(\exists n\le N: X_{n}\in A\,|\, X_{0}=i)qi(N)​=P(∃n≤N:Xn​∈A∣X0​=i)so qi(N)=∑jpijqj(N−1)q_{i}^{(N)}=\sum_{j}p_{ij}q_{j}^{(N-1)}qi(N)​=∑j​pij​qj(N−1)​, and induction on NNN gives ∀N,qi(N)≤xi\forall N, q_{i}^{(N)}\le x_{i}∀N,qi(N)​≤xi​.
Hence xi≥lim⁡N→∞qi(N)=P{⋃N{∃n≤N:Xn∈A ∣ X0=i}}=P{∃n:Xn∈A}=hiA\begin{align*} x_{i}\ge \lim_{ N \to \infty }q_{i}^{(N)}&=\mathbb{P}\Big\{\bigcup_{N}\{\exists n\le N: X_{n}\in A\,|\, X_{0}=i\} \Big\} \\&=\mathbb{P}\{\exists n: X_{n}\in A\}\\ &=h_{i}^{A} \end{align*}xi​≥N→∞lim​qi(N)​​=P{N⋃​{∃n≤N:Xn​∈A∣X0​=i}}=P{∃n:Xn​∈A}=hiA​​

Recurrence and Transience

Big idea: recurrence and transcience describes whether a Markov chain will indefinitely return to a particular state.

  • For convenience, denote the return probability as ri=P(∃n≥0:Xn=i ∣ X0=i)r_{i}=\mathbb{P}(\exists n\ge{0}: X_{n}=i\,|\, X_{0}=i)ri​=P(∃n≥0:Xn​=i∣X0​=i)but this notation is not standard, so remember to define it explicitly for exams.

  • A state i∈Ii\in Ii∈I is transient if ri<1r_{i}<1ri​<1, which means that P(the chain hits i infinitely many times ∣ X0=i)=lim⁡k→∞rik=0\mathbb{P}(\text{the chain hits } i \text{ infinitely many times}\,|\, X_0=i)=\lim_{ k \to \infty }r_{i}^k =0P(the chain hits i infinitely many times∣X0​=i)=k→∞lim​rik​=0

  • A state i∈Ii\in Ii∈I is recurrent if ri=1r_{i}=1ri​=1, which means that P(the chain hits i infinitely many times ∣ X0=i)=lim⁡k→∞rik=1\mathbb{P}(\text{the chain hits } i \text{ infinitely many times}\,|\, X_0=i)=\lim_{ k \to \infty }r_{i}^k =1P(the chain hits i infinitely many times∣X0​=i)=k→∞lim​rik​=1

  • A state iii is recurrent if and only if ∑n≥1pii(n)=∞\sum_{n\ge 1} p_{ii}^{(n)}=\infty∑n≥1​pii(n)​=∞.

Proof: the total number of hits has expectation ∑nE[1(Xn=i) ∣ X0=i]=∑nP(Xn=i ∣ X0=i)=∑npii(n)\sum_{n} \mathbb{E}[\mathbf{1}(X_{n}=i)\,|\, X_{0}=i]=\sum_{n}\mathbb{P}(X_{n}=i\,|\, X_{0}=i)=\sum_{n}p_{ii}^{(n)}n∑​E[1(Xn​=i)∣X0​=i]=n∑​P(Xn​=i∣X0​=i)=n∑​pii(n)​Then (the state is recurrent)   ⟺  \iff⟺ (the expected number of hits is infinite)   ⟺  \iff⟺ (the sum is infinite).

  • Recurrence/transience is a class property: states in the same communicating class are either all recurrent or all transient.
  • Recurrent classes are all closed; all finite, closed classes are recurrent.

The two propositions are proved in problem sheet 3.

Hitting and Return Times

  • The (first) hitting time of set A⊆IA \subseteq IA⊆I is a random variable taking the values HA=inf⁡{n≥0:Xn∈A}H^A=\inf\{n\ge 0: X_{n}\in A\}HA=inf{n≥0:Xn​∈A}
  • The mean hitting time of AAA from iii is kiA=E[HA ∣ X0=i]k_{i}^{A}=\mathbb{E}[H^{A}\,|\, X_{0}=i]kiA​=E[HA∣X0​=i]
  • The mean hitting times of the Markov chain (ki∈IA)(k_{i\in I}^A)(ki∈IA​) is the minimal non-negative solution to the equations kiA={0 if i∈A1+∑jpijkjA if i∉Ak_{i}^A=\begin{cases} 0 &\text{ if }i\in A \\ 1+\sum_{j}p_{ij}k_{j}^{A} & \text{ if } i\notin A \end{cases}kiA​={01+∑j​pij​kjA​​ if i∈A if i∈/A​

The proof uses the same strategy as the proof for hitting probabilities.

  • The mean return time of a state iii ismi=E[inf⁡{n≥1:Xn=i} ∣ X0=i]m_{i}=\mathbb{E}[\inf\{n\ge 1: X_{n}=i\}\,|\, X_{0}=i]mi​=E[inf{n≥1:Xn​=i}∣X0​=i]That is, the expected time to return to the state after starting from it.
  • A recurrent state with a finite mean return time is called positive recurrent; else it is null recurrent.
  • A transient state always has a mean return time of ∞\infty∞, since it has a positive probability of never returning.

Gambler’s Ruin as a Markov Chain

  • Model

The possession of the gambler at time ttt is XtX_{t}Xt​, and the winning probability as ppp. They starts with KaTeX parse error: Undefined control sequence: \textsterling at position 7: X_{0}=\̲t̲e̲x̲t̲s̲t̲e̲r̲l̲i̲n̲g̲ ̲n.
The transition probabilities are pij={p if j=i+1, i≠0q=1−p if j=i−1, i≠00 if otherwisep_{ij}=\begin{cases} p &\text{ if } j=i+1,\ i\ne 0 \\ q=1-p &\text{ if } j=i-1,\ i\ne 0 \\ 0 &\text{ if otherwise} \end{cases}pij​=⎩⎨⎧​pq=1−p0​ if j=i+1, i=0 if j=i−1, i=0 if otherwise​

  • Hitting probabilities

The probability of hitting zero starting from state iii, (hi)(h_{i})(hi​), comes from the equationsh0=1hi≠0=∑jpijhj=phi+1+qhi−1\begin{align*} h_{0}&=1 \\ h_{i\ne 0} &= \sum_{j}p_{ij}h_{j}=ph_{i+1}+qh_{i-1} \end{align*}h0​hi=0​​=1=j∑​pij​hj​=phi+1​+qhi−1​​which has the general solution hi=A+B(qp)ih_{i}=A+B\big( \frac{q}{p}\big)^ihi​=A+B(pq​)i, where h0=1h_{0}=1h0​=1 requires A+B=1A+B=1A+B=1.
Then non-negativity and minimality requires (A,B)={(1,0) if p≤q(0,1) if p>q(A,B)=\begin{cases} (1,0) &\text{ if }p\le q \\ (0,1) &\text{ if }p>q \\ \end{cases}(A,B)={(1,0)(0,1)​ if p≤q if p>q​So the hitting probability is 111 in the first case, and (q/p)i(q / p)^{i}(q/p)i in the second case.

  • Transience/Recurrence

The state 000 is obviously recurrent, since it is an absorbing state.

The rest of the chain communicate, so it is sufficient to find the transience/recurrence of the state 111. Its return probability is r1<p<1r_{1}<p<1r1​<p<1, so it is transient. Hence the entire class {1,2,… }\{1,2,\dots \}{1,2,…} is transient.

The lecture notes studies the modified chain where p01>0p_{01}>0p01​>0, which makes the chain irreducible, and we can find the return probability and mean return time to 000.

  • Mean hitting time of 000

If p>qp > qp>q, hitting probability is (q/p)i<1(q / p)^i<1(q/p)i<1, so the mean hitting time is infinite.

If p≤qp\le qp≤q, the mean hitting times (ki)(k_{i})(ki​) solve the equations k0=1ki≠0=1+∑jpijkj=1+pki+1+qki−1\begin{align*} k_{0}&=1 \\ k_{i\ne 0} &= 1+\sum_{j}p_{ij}k_{j}=1+pk_{i+1}+qk_{i-1} \end{align*}k0​ki=0​​=1=1+j∑​pij​kj​=1+pki+1​+qki−1​​
The lecture notes involve some Olympic-level hand-waving to claim ki=βik_{i}=\beta iki​=βi, and the answer follows. To see why, note that ki=E[time to hit (i−1) from i]+ki−1=k1+ki−1\begin{align*} k_{i}&= \mathbb{E}[\text{time to hit }(i-1) \text{ from }i]+k_{i-1}\\ &= k_{1} +k_{i-1} \end{align*}ki​​=E[time to hit (i−1) from i]+ki−1​=k1​+ki−1​​by memorilessness. Then β=k1\beta=k_{1}β=k1​.

When p<qp<qp<q, solving gives ki=i/(q−p)k_{i}=i / (q-p)ki​=i/(q−p).

When p=qp=qp=q, any finite β=k1\beta=k_{1}β=k1​ failes, hence the mean hitting times (ki)(k_{i})(ki​) must be all be infinite.

Equilibrium and Convergence of Markov Chains

Recap: Markov Chain as Matrix Multiplication

  • The distribution of the Markov chain variable XnX_{n}Xn​ can be expressed as a row vector λ(t)\lambda(t)λ(t) of length ∣I∣|I|∣I∣.
  • As noted under the Chapman-Kolmogorov equations, right-multiplying the transition matrix PPP moves the distribution forward in time: with λ(t)\lambda(t)λ(t) as the distribution of XtX_{t}Xt​, then for n≥m,n\ge m,n≥m,λ(n)=λ(m)Pn−m\lambda(n)=\lambda(m)P^{n-m}λ(n)=λ(m)Pn−m
  • In particular, if λ0\lambda_{0}λ0​ is the initial distribution of X0X_{0}X0​, then the distribution of XnX_{n}Xn​ is λ0Pn\lambda_{0} P^nλ0​Pn.

Stationary distributions and Convergence Theorems

  • A distribution π\piπ is a stationary distribution of a Markov chain with transition matrix PPP if it is the left-eigenvector of PPP with eigenvalue 111: π=πP\pi=\pi Pπ=πPNote that it is the left-eigenvector, not the usual right-eigenvector.

    • That is, the transition matrix does not change the stationary distribution over time.

  • Existence and uniqueness of the stationary distribution: if PPP is irreducible, then P positive-recurrent  ⟺  ∃!π stationary, where  πi=1miP \text{ positive-recurrent} \iff\exists!\pi \text{ stationary, where }\,\pi_{i}=\frac{1}{m_{i}}P positive-recurrent⟺∃!π stationary, where πi​=mi​1​where mim_{i}mi​ is the mean return time to state iii.

  • Convergence to the stationary distribution: if PPP is irreducible and aperiodic with stationary distribution π\piπ, any initial distribution has ∀i,j:\forall i,j:∀i,j: P(Xn=j)→πjpij(n)→πj\begin{align*} \mathbb{P}(X_{n}=j)\to \pi_{j}\\ p_{ij}^{(n)}\to \pi_{j} \end{align*}P(Xn​=j)→πj​pij(n)​→πj​​

    • Aperiodicity is important, as a periodic chain “remembers” its initial distribution.

  • Ergodic Theorem: for irreducible chains, the proportion of time spent on state iii converges to 1/mi1 / m_{i}1/mi​ almost surely: Let Vi(n)=∑t=0n−11(Xt=1) be the number of visits before time n,then Vi(n)n→1mi a.s.\begin{align*} &\text{Let }V_{i}(n)=\sum_{t=0}^{n-1}\mathbf{1}(X_{t}=1) \text{ be the number of visits before time }n,\\ &\text{then }\frac{V_{i}(n)}{n}\to \frac{1}{m_{i}} \text{ a.s.} \end{align*}​Let Vi​(n)=t=0∑n−1​1(Xt​=1) be the number of visits before time n,then nVi​(n)​→mi​1​ a.s.​for null-recurrent and transient states, we interpret 1/mi1 / m_{i}1/mi​ to be 000.

The proofs of the three theorems in this section are not examinable.

Poisson Processes

Definitions

  • A Poisson process models the occurance of events in continuous time; it is represented by a random variable NtN_{t}Nt​, which counts the number of events that happen before time ttt.
  • The kkkth arrival time is Tk=inf⁡{t≥0:Nt≥k}T_{k}=\inf \{ t\ge 0:N_{t}\ge k \}Tk​=inf{t≥0:Nt​≥k}.
  • The kkkth interarrival time is Yk=Tk−Tk−1Y_{k}=T_{k}-T_{k-1}Yk​=Tk​−Tk−1​.
  • The rate of the process is a constant λ∈R\lambda\in \mathbb{R}λ∈R, which is the mean number of arrivals per unit time.
  • The exponential interarrival time definition of Poisson processes: a counting process is Poisson with rate λ\lambdaλ if its interarrival times are iid. Exp(λ)\text{Exp}(\lambda)Exp(λ).
  • The Poisson increment definition of Poisson processes: a counting process NtN_{t}Nt​ is Poisson with rate λ\lambdaλ if:
    • its increments over disjoint time intervals are independent,
    • (Nt+d−Nt)∼Poisson(λd)(N_{t+d}-N_{t}) \sim\text{Poisson}(\lambda d)(Nt+d​−Nt​)∼Poisson(λd) for any ttt,
    • N0=0N_{0}=0N0​=0.
  • The two definitions are equivalent.

See the lecture notes for the proof. It’s too long for me to bother summarizing it, and it’s probably not examinable.

Superposition and Thinning of Poisson Processes

  • Superposition: given two independent Poisson counting processes LtL_{t}Lt​ and MtM_{t}Mt​ with rates λ\lambdaλ and μ\muμ, their sum Nt=Lt+MtN_{t}=L_{t}+M_{t}Nt​=Lt​+Mt​ is also a Poisson process with rate (λ+μ)(\lambda+\mu)(λ+μ).
    • That is, poisson plus poisson is still poisson.

Proof: verify that NtN_{t}Nt​ satisfies the poisson increment definition of Poisson processes.

  • Thinning: given a Poisson process NtN_{t}Nt​ with rate λ\lambdaλ, if an occurance is not always counted, but only with probability ppp (independently), it still is a Poisson process with rate λp\lambda pλp.
    • That is, randomly sampled Poisson is still Poisson.

The lecture notes has a proof using the poisson increment definition, while the following is an alternative using the exponential interarrival time definition.

Proof: after the thinning, the interarrival time isY~=∑k=1NYk\tilde Y=\sum_{k={1}}^{N} Y_{k}Y~=k=1∑N​Yk​where N∼geo(p)N\sim \text{geo}(p)N∼geo(p).
Then MY~(t)=GR(MYk(t))M_{\tilde{Y}}(t)=G_{R}\big(M_{Y_{k}}(t)\big)MY~​(t)=GR​(MYk​​(t)) as shown in the “extra” theorem in the section Using Moment Generating Functions. We can then verify that Y~\tilde YY~ has the same mgf as Exp(pλ)\text{Exp}(p\lambda)Exp(pλ).# A8 - Probability

Convergence of Random Variables

  • A sequence of variables (Xn)(X_n)(Xn​) converges almost surely to XXX, written as Xn→X a.s.X_n\to X\text{ a.s.}Xn​→X a.s., ifP(Xn→X)≡P{ω:(Xn(ω))→X(ω)}=1\mathbb P(X_n\to X)\equiv\mathbb P\Big\{\omega:\big(X_n(\omega)\big)\to X(\omega)\Big\}=1P(Xn​→X)≡P{ω:(Xn​(ω))→X(ω)}=1where ω\omegaω is some event, and X(ω)X(\omega)X(ω) denotes the value XXX takes when ω\omegaω occurs.
    • That is, the times where the value of Xn↛XX_n\not\to XXn​→X are negligible (i.e. they form a null set), or Xn→X a.e.X_{n} \to X \,\mathrm{a.e.}Xn​→Xa.e. in the space of events.
  • (Xn)(X_n)(Xn​) converges in probability to XXX, written as XnundefinedPXX_n\xrightarrow{P}XXn​P​X, ifP(∣Xn−X∣<ϵ)→1, ∀ϵ>0\mathbb P(|X_n-X|<\epsilon)\to 1,\ \forall \epsilon>0P(∣Xn​−X∣<ϵ)→1, ∀ϵ>0
    • That is, each XnX_nXn​ is likely to be within a disk around XXX, but not necessarily likely enough to converge (it could pop outside every now and then).
  • (Xn)(X_n)(Xn​) converges in distribution to XXX, written as XnundefineddXX_n\xrightarrow{d}XXn​d​X, if ∀x where F continuous, Fn(x)→F(x)\forall x \text{ where } F\text{ continuous},\, F_n(x)\to F(x)∀x where F continuous,Fn​(x)→F(x)
    • that is, XnX_nXn​ will have a similar distribution to XXX, but they could be independent
    • There is no requirement at points where FFF is discontinuous.

Descending Strength of Convergences

  • Convergence a.s.  undefined(1) \,\xRightarrow{(1)}\,(1)​ convergence in probability  undefined(2) \,\xRightarrow{(2)}\,(2)​ convergence in distribution, while the converse is not true in general.
  • Proof of (1)(1)(1):

Fix ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0, define AN:{event ω:∀n≥N:∣Xn(ω)−X(ω)∣<ϵ}A_N:\{\text{event }\omega:\forall n\ge N:|X_n(\omega)-X(\omega)|<\epsilon\}AN​:{event ω:∀n≥N:∣Xn​(ω)−X(ω)∣<ϵ},
Then almost-sure convergence guarantees ANA_NAN​ occurs at least for some NNN, so P(⋃AN)=1\mathbb P(\bigcup A_N)=1P(⋃AN​)=1.
Since ANA_NAN​ is an increasing sequence of events, P(AN)→1\mathbb P(A_N)\to 1P(AN​)→1. ∗^{*}∗
Since ANA_NAN​ implies ∣Xn≥N−X∣<ϵ,|X_{n \ge N}-X|<\epsilon,∣Xn≥N​−X∣<ϵ, convergence in probability follows.

∗^{*}∗This is a standard result for P:F→R\mathbb{P}:\mathcal{F} \to \mathbb{R}P:F→R as a Lebesgue measure.

  • Counterexample of (1)(1)(1) converse:

Consider independent random variables XnX_nXn​ with distribution P(Xn=0)=n−1n,  P(Xn=1)=1n \mathbb{P}(X_{n}=0)=\frac{n-1}{n},\,\, \mathbb P(X_n=1)=\frac{1}{n} P(Xn​=0)=nn−1​,P(Xn​=1)=n1​Then XnundefinedP0X_n\xrightarrow{P}0Xn​P​0, but P(∀n≥N:Xn=0)=0\mathbb P(\forall n\ge N: X_n=0)=0P(∀n≥N:Xn​=0)=0 for any NNN, so almost-sure convergence failes.

  • Proof of (2)(2)(2):

Since Xn<xX_n<xXn​<x implies X<x+ϵX<x+\epsilonX<x+ϵ or ∣X−Xn∣≥ϵ|X-X_n|\ge \epsilon∣X−Xn​∣≥ϵ for any positive ϵ,\epsilon,ϵ,
Fn(x)=P(Xn≤x)≤P[(X<x+ϵ) OR (∣X−Xn∣≥ϵ)]≤P(X<x+ϵ)+P(∣X−Xn∣>ϵ)→F(x+ϵ)\begin{align*} F_n(x)&=\mathbb P(X_n\le x)\\ &\le\mathbb P\big[(X<x+\epsilon)\text{ OR }(|X-X_n|\geq\epsilon)\big]\\ &\le \mathbb P(X<x+\epsilon)+\mathbb P(|X-X_n |>\epsilon) \\&\to F(x+\epsilon)\end{align*}Fn​(x)​=P(Xn​≤x)≤P[(X<x+ϵ) OR (∣X−Xn​∣≥ϵ)]≤P(X<x+ϵ)+P(∣X−Xn​∣>ϵ)→F(x+ϵ)​
Similar logic applied to 1−Fn(x)=P(Xn>x)1-F_n(x)=\mathbb P(X_n> x)1−Fn​(x)=P(Xn​>x) gives Fn(x)≥F(x−ϵ)F_{n}(x) \ge F(x-\epsilon)Fn​(x)≥F(x−ϵ).
Continuity of FFF at xxx makes F(x±ϵ)→F(x)F(x \pm \epsilon) \to F(x)F(x±ϵ)→F(x), so they sandwich Fn(x)→F(x)F_n(x)\to F(x)Fn​(x)→F(x).

  • Counterexample of (2)(2)(2) converse:

Let Y,X1,X2,…iid.Y,X_1, X_2,\dots iid.Y,X1​,X2​,…iid. (for example N(0,1)N(0,1)N(0,1)), then XnundefineddY,X_n\xrightarrow{d} Y,Xn​d​Y, but ↛Y\nrightarrow Y↛Y in probability.

  • Nevertheless, (2)(2)(2) converse is true if XnundefineddcX_{n} \xrightarrow{d} cXn​d​c constant; in that case XnundefinedPcX_{n} \xrightarrow{P}cXn​P​c.

Proof: fix any ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0. Then lim⁡n→∞P[∣Xn−c∣<ϵ]=lim⁡n→∞[Fn(c+ϵ)−Fn(c−ϵ)]=lim⁡n→∞[Fn(c+ϵ)]−lim⁡n→∞[Fn(c−ϵ)]=F(c+ϵ)−F(c−ϵ)=1\begin{align*} \lim_{ n \to \infty } \mathbb{P}[|X_{n}-c| < \epsilon]&= \lim_{ n \to \infty } \Big[F_{n}(c+\epsilon)-F_{n}(c-\epsilon)\Big]\\ &= \lim_{ n \to \infty } [F_{n}(c+\epsilon)] - \lim_{ n \to \infty } [F_{n}(c-\epsilon)]\\ &= F(c+\epsilon) - F(c-\epsilon)\\ &= 1 \end{align*}n→∞lim​P[∣Xn​−c∣<ϵ]​=n→∞lim​[Fn​(c+ϵ)−Fn​(c−ϵ)]=n→∞lim​[Fn​(c+ϵ)]−n→∞lim​[Fn​(c−ϵ)]=F(c+ϵ)−F(c−ϵ)=1​where the third equality uses Fn(c±ϵ)→F(c±ϵ)F_{n}(c \pm \epsilon) \to F(c \pm \epsilon)Fn​(c±ϵ)→F(c±ϵ); this is because FFF is continuous anywhere bar x=cx=cx=c, in particular c±ϵc \pm \epsilonc±ϵ.

Convergence Laws

  • the Strong Law of Large Numbers states that given random variables X1,⋯ ,nX_{1,\cdots, n}X1,⋯,n​ i.i.d. with mean μ\muμ, then their average Xˉ=∑Xn→μ a.s.\bar{X}=\frac{\sum X}{n}\to\mu\text{ a.s.}Xˉ=n∑X​→μ a.s..

Proof non-examinable.

  • the Central Limit Theorem states that under the same conditions as above, with σ2\sigma^2σ2 being the variance, there is: Xˉ−μσ/n=∑iXi−nμσnundefineddN(0,1)\frac{\bar{X}-\mu}{\sigma/\sqrt{n}}=\frac{\sum_{i} X_{i}-n\mu}{\sigma\sqrt{n}}\xrightarrow{d}N(0,1)σ/n​Xˉ−μ​=σn​∑i​Xi​−nμ​d​N(0,1)
    So roughly, Mn≈N(μ,σn)M_n \approx N(\mu, \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}})Mn​≈N(μ,n​σ​).

The proof is in the next section.

Generating Functions

  • As learned in Prelims, the probability generating function (pgf) of a variable X∈NX \in \mathbb{N}X∈N is GX(t)=E[tX]G_{X}(t)=\mathbb{E}[t^{X}]GX​(t)=E[tX]It is restricted to discrete variables with non-negative integer values, so we want something more general.

Moment Generating Functions

  • The moment generating function (mgf) of a random variable XXX is MX(t)=E[etX]M_X(t)=\mathbb E[e^{tX}]MX​(t)=E[etX]
  • The Taylor series of the mgf “generates” the moment of the variable: with mk=E[Xk]m_k=\mathbb E[X^k]mk​=E[Xk] being the mmmth moment of XXX (about the point 000), MX(t)=∑k=0∞tkmkk!,M_X(t)=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \frac{t^km_k}{k!},MX​(t)=k=0∑∞​k!tkmk​​,
    • Hence MX(k)(0)=mk=E[Xk]M_X^{(k)}(0)=m_k=\mathbb E[X^k]MX(k)​(0)=mk​=E[Xk].
  • For the mgf to converge, XXX needs an exponentially decaying tail: the “tail” of its distribution that decays as fast as the exponential.
    • The normal and the poisson distributions have super-exponential tails (i.e. faster-than-exponential).
    • The exponential, geometric, and gamma distributions have exponential tails.
    • Distributions with polynomial tails do not decay fast enough, hence their mgfs might be undefined at places, if at all.

Using Moment Generating Functions

Big idea: mgfs determine the distribution, so combining variables is equivalent to combining their mgfs.

  • Uniqueness: if X,YX,YX,Y have the same mgf, finite over some closed disk around 000, then they have the same distribution.
  • Continuity: if (Yn):MYn→MY(Y_n):M_{Y_n}\to M_Y(Yn​):MYn​​→MY​, all finite over some closed disk around 000, then XnundefineddYX_n\xrightarrow{d}YXn​d​Y.

Both proofs are beyond the course so not examinable. Great.

  • Distribution of sums of random variables: given iid. X1,…,nX_{1,\dots,n}X1,…,n​, their sum YYY has mgf MY(t)=∏nMXn(t)M_Y(t)=\prod_n M_{X_n}(t)MY​(t)=n∏​MXn​​(t)If we can recognize MYM_{Y}MY​ as the mgf of some distribution DDD, uniqueness of mgf then gives Y∼DY \sim DY∼D.

  • Example: independent variables X1∼N(μ1,σ12)X_{1}\sim N(\mu_{1},\sigma_{1}^{2})X1​∼N(μ1​,σ12​) and X2∼N(μ2,σ22)X_{2} \sim N(\mu_{2},\sigma_{2}^{2})X2​∼N(μ2​,σ22​) have the sum X1+X2=Y∼N(μ1+μ2,σ12+σ22)X_{1}+X_{2}=Y \sim N(\mu_{1}+\mu_{2},\sigma_{1}^{2}+\sigma_{2}^{2})X1​+X2​=Y∼N(μ1​+μ2​,σ12​+σ22​)

Proof: note that the standard normal has mgf et2/2e^{t^{2}/ 2}et2/2.
The mgf of XiX_{i}Xi​ is then Mi=exp⁡(μit+(σit)2/2)M_{i}=\exp(\mu_{i} t+(\sigma_{i} t)^{2} / 2)Mi​=exp(μi​t+(σi​t)2/2).
Their sum YYY has mgf MY=M1(t)M2(t)=exp⁡((μ1+μ2)t+(σ12+σ22)t22)\begin{align*} M_{Y}&= M_{1}(t)M_{2}(t)\\ &= \exp\left( (\mu_{1}+\mu_{2})t+\frac{(\sigma_{1}^{2}+\sigma_{2}^{2})t^{2}}{2} \right) \end{align*}MY​​=M1​(t)M2​(t)=exp((μ1​+μ2​)t+2(σ12​+σ22​)t2​)​which is the mgf of N(μ1+μ2,σ12+σ22)N(\mu_{1}+\mu_{2},\sigma_{1}^{2}+\sigma_{2}^{2})N(μ1​+μ2​,σ12​+σ22​). By the continuity property, Y∼N(μ1+μ2,σ12+σ22)Y \sim N(\mu_{1}+\mu_{2},\sigma_{1}^{2}+\sigma_{2}^{2})Y∼N(μ1​+μ2​,σ12​+σ22​).

  • Proof of the weak law of large numbers with mgf:

The average has mgf M∑X/n(t)=[MX(t/n)]n=(1+μt/n+O((t/n)2))n→etμM_{\sum X/n}(t)=\big[M_X(t/n)\big]^n=\big(1+\mu t / n+O((t / n)^{2})\big)^n\to e^{t\mu}M∑X/n​(t)=[MX​(t/n)]n=(1+μt/n+O((t/n)2))n→etμThis is the mgf of the constant μ\muμ. By continuity ∑X/nundefineddμ\sum X/n\xrightarrow{d}\mu∑X/nd​μ.

  • Proof of the CLT with mgf:

Define Yk=Xk−μY_k=X_k-\muYk​=Xk​−μ, with mgf MY(t)=1+σ22t2+o(t3)M_Y(t)=1+\frac{\sigma^2}{2}t^2 +o(t^3)MY​(t)=1+2σ2​t2+o(t3) near 000.
Then the variable (∑X−nμ)/(σn)(\sum X-n\mu)/(\sigma\sqrt{n})(∑X−nμ)/(σn​) has mgf Mn=(MY(tσn))n=(1+12nt2+O(t3n−3/2))n→exp⁡(t2/2),M_n=\Big(M_Y\big(\frac{t}{\sigma\sqrt n}\big)\Big)^n=\big(1+\frac{1}{2n}t^2+O(t^3n^{-3/2})\big)^n\to\exp(t^2/2),Mn​=(MY​(σn​t​))n=(1+2n1​t2+O(t3n−3/2))n→exp(t2/2), This is the mgf of N(0,1)N(0,1)N(0,1). Again by continuity, (∑X−nμ)/(σn)undefineddN(0,1)(\sum X-n\mu)/(\sigma\sqrt{n})\xrightarrow{d} N(0,1)(∑X−nμ)/(σn​)d​N(0,1).

  • Extra: given iid. random variables X1,X2,…X_{1},X_{2},\dotsX1​,X2​,…, and an integer-valued random variable NNN, with pgf GNG_{N}GN​, then the mgf of Y=X1+⋯+XNY=X_{1}+\dots+X_{N}Y=X1​+⋯+XN​ is MY(t)=GN(MXk(t))M_{Y}(t)=G_{N}\Big(M_{X_{k}}(t)\Big)MY​(t)=GN​(MXk​​(t))

Characteristic Function

  • The characteristic function of a random variable XXX is: ϕX(t)=E[eiXt]\phi_X(t)=\mathbb E[e^{iXt}]ϕX​(t)=E[eiXt]
    • That is, exit.
  • The characteristic function can be obtained by replacing ttt with ititit in mgfs (where they converge).
    • For example, the standard normal has mgf exp⁡(t22)\exp\left( \frac{t^2}{2} \right)exp(2t2​), hence a characteristic function of exp⁡(−t22)\exp\left( -\frac{t^2}{2} \right)exp(−2t2​).
  • Characteristic functions do not require exponentially decaying tails for convergence as a complex series (unlike the mgf).

Joint Distributions

  • The joint cumulative density function (cdf) of two random variables X,YX,YX,Y is FX,Y(x,y)=P(X≤x,Y≤y)F_{X,Y}(x,y)=\mathbb P(X\le x,Y\le y)FX,Y​(x,y)=P(X≤x,Y≤y)

  • The two variables are jointly continuous if this function can be written as a double integral: ∃f(x,y):F(x,y)=∫−∞y∫−∞xf(r,s) dr ds\exists f(x,y): F(x,y)=\int_{-\infty}^{y} \int_{-\infty}^{x} f(r,s)\,dr\,ds ∃f(x,y):F(x,y)=∫−∞y​∫−∞x​f(r,s)drdsand the function fff is the joint probability density function (pdf).

  • Given the joint pdf, A⊆R2A\subseteq \mathbb R^2A⊆R2, P((X,Y)∈A)=∬Af dA\mathbb P\big((X,Y)\in A\big)=\iint_{A}f \, dAP((X,Y)∈A)=∬A​fdA

  • The marginal distribution of XXX is obtained by integrating out YYY: fX(x)=∫−∞∞fX,Y(x,y) dyf_{X}( x)=\int_{-\infty}^\infty f_{X,Y}(x,y) \, dy fX​(x)=∫−∞∞​fX,Y​(x,y)dy

  • If variables X,YX,YX,Y are independent, fX,Y(x,y)=fX(x)fY(y)f_{X,Y}(x,y)=f_{X}(x)f_{Y}(y)fX,Y​(x,y)=fX​(x)fY​(y)Hence given independence, the marginal distribution can be found by factoring.

Conditional Densities

  • We can define the conditional cdf for an event AAA: FX∣A(x)=P(X≤x∩A)P(A)F_{X|A}(x)=\frac{\mathbb{P}(X\le x \cap A)}{\mathbb P(A)}FX∣A​(x)=P(A)P(X≤x∩A)​ and the conditional pdf fX∣A(x)f_{X|A}(x)fX∣A​(x) is its derivative.
  • Then the conditional probability and expectation areP(X∈C ∣ A)=∫CfX∣A(x) dxE(X∣A)=∫x⋅fX∣A(x) dx\begin{align*} \mathbb{P}(X\in C\,|\,A)&=\int_{C}f_{X|A}(x) \, dx\\ \mathbb{E}(X|A)&=\int x\cdot f_{X|A}(x) \, dx \end{align*}P(X∈C∣A)E(X∣A)​=∫C​fX∣A​(x)dx=∫x⋅fX∣A​(x)dx​
  • The conditional density function of YYY given X=xX=xX=x is: fY∣X=x(y)=fX,YfXf_{Y|X=x}(y)=\frac{f_{X,Y}}{f_{X}}fY∣X=x​(y)=fX​fX,Y​​ for x:fX(x)≠0x:f_{X}(x)\ne 0x:fX​(x)=0.

Transformation Formula in 2D

  • Consider the transformation from random variables X,YX,YX,Y to T(x,y)=(U(x,y),V(x,y))T(x,y)=\big(U(x,y),V(x,y)\big)T(x,y)=(U(x,y),V(x,y)). Suppose (X,Y)(X,Y)(X,Y) has non-000 density in R⊆R2R \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{2}R⊆R2.

  • The transformation formula gives the distribution of U,VU,VU,V: in the region T(R)T(R)T(R), their density is fU,V(u,v)=fX,Y(x(u,v),y(u,v))∣det⁡∂(u,v)∂(x,y)∣f_{U,V}(u,v)=f_{X,Y}\Big(x(u,v),y(u,v)\Big)\Bigg|\det\frac{\partial(u,v)}{\partial(x,y)}\Bigg|fU,V​(u,v)=fX,Y​(x(u,v),y(u,v))∣∣​det∂(x,y)∂(u,v)​∣∣​where ∂(u,v)∂(x,y)\frac{\partial(u,v)}{\partial(x,y)}∂(x,y)∂(u,v)​ is the Jacobian (matrix) J=∂(u,v)∂(x,y)=(uxuyvxvy)J=\frac{\partial(u,v)}{\partial(x,y)}=\begin{pmatrix} u_{x} & u_{y} \\ v_{x} & v_{y} \end{pmatrix}J=∂(x,y)∂(u,v)​=(ux​vx​​uy​vy​​)and outside T(R)T(R)T(R), fU,V(u,v)=0f_{U,V}(u,v)=0fU,V​(u,v)=0.

Proof: for any A⊆RA\subseteq RA⊆R, there is T(A)⊆T(R)T(A)\subseteq T(R)T(A)⊆T(R), so we can write P((X,Y)∈A)=P((U,V)∈T(A))\mathbb P\big((X,Y)\in A\big)=\mathbb P\big((U,V)\in T(A)\big)P((X,Y)∈A)=P((U,V)∈T(A))as a double integral, and apply the change-of-variable theorm learned in Prelims multivariable calculus.

  • Example: deriving the distribution of the sum of two random variables.

Transform from (X,Y)(X,Y)(X,Y) to (X+Y,Y)(X+Y,Y)(X+Y,Y) with a Jacobian of determinant 111, and substitute XXX with X=(X+Y)−YX=(X+Y)-YX=(X+Y)−Y, we havefX+Y, Y(u,v)=fX,Y(u−v,v)⋅1f_{X+Y,\,Y}(u,v)=f_{X,Y}(u-v,v)\cdot 1fX+Y,Y​(u,v)=fX,Y​(u−v,v)⋅1so integrating gives the marginal distribution, fX+Y(u)=∫−∞∞fX,Y(u−v,v) dvf_{X+Y}(u)=\int _{-\infty}^\infty f_{X,Y}(u-v,v)\, dv fX+Y​(u)=∫−∞∞​fX,Y​(u−v,v)dv

Transformations and Gaussians in Higher Dimensions

  • The same formula holds for higher dimensions, where the Jacobian has the entries defined as (∂(x1,…,xn)∂(y1,…,yn))i,j=∂xi∂yj\Bigg( \frac{\partial(x_{1},\dots,x_{n})}{\partial(y_{1},\dots, y_{n})}\Bigg )_{i,j}=\frac{\partial x_{i}}{\partial y_{j}}(∂(y1​,…,yn​)∂(x1​,…,xn​)​)i,j​=∂yj​∂xi​​

  • For linear transformations W=AZ+μ\mathbf{W}=A\mathbf{Z}+\mathbf{\mu}W=AZ+μ, the Jacobian is just A−1A^{-1}A−1, hence fW(w)=fZ(z(w))∣det⁡A∣f_{\mathbf{W}}(\mathbf{w})=\frac{f_{\mathbf{Z}}(\mathbf{z}(\mathbf{w}))}{|\det A|}fW​(w)=∣detA∣fZ​(z(w))​

  • For example, given iid. standard normal variables Z\mathbf{Z}Z, the transformed W=AZ+μ‾\mathbf{W}=A\mathbf{Z}+\underline{\mu}W=AZ+μ​ would have distribution fW(w)=1(2π)n/2∣det⁡A∣exp⁡(−12(w−μ‾)T(AAT)−1(w−μ‾))f_{\mathbf{W}}(\mathbf{w})=\frac{1}{(2\pi)^{n/2}|\det A|}\exp\left( -\frac{1}{2}(\mathbf{ w-\underline{\mu}})^T(AA^T)^{-1}(\mathbf{ w-\underline{\mu}}) \right)fW​(w)=(2π)n/2∣detA∣1​exp(−21​(w−μ​)T(AAT)−1(w−μ​))(You probably don’t need to memorize this…) so they follow the multivariate normal distribution N(μ‾,AAT)N(\underline{\mu},A A^T)N(μ​,AAT), where AATA A^{T}AAT is the covariance matrix.

  • The covariance matrix of random variables X1,…,XnX_{1},\dots,X_{n}X1​,…,Xn​ is the matrix Σn×n\Sigma_{n\times n}Σn×n​ where (Σ)ij=Cov(Xi,Xj)(\Sigma)_{ij}=\mathrm{Cov}(X_{i},X_{j})(Σ)ij​=Cov(Xi​,Xj​)So independent variables have a diagonal covariance matrix. While the converse is not true in general, it does hold for Gaussians…

  • If the multivariate Gaussian W=(W1,…,Wn)\mathbf{W}=(W_{1},\dots,W_{n})W=(W1​,…,Wn​) has an orthogonal covariance matrix AAA, i.e. AAT=IA A^{T}=IAAT=I, then its pdf can be factored as fW=∏i=1nfwi(wi)f_{\mathbf{W}}=\prod_{i=1}^{n}f_{w_{i}}(w_{i})fW​=i=1∏n​fwi​​(wi​)So W1,…,WnW_{1},\dots,W_{n}W1​,…,Wn​ are indeed independent.

    • Here AAA is called “orthogonal”; a similar result holds for AAT=diag(… )AA^{T}=\mathrm{diag}(\dots)AAT=diag(…), but the algebra is even messier.

A Random Section on Constructing Normal Variables

  • Goal: construct two random normal variables X,YX,YX,Y following N(m,s){N}(m,s)N(m,s) and N(μ,σ){N}(\mu,\sigma)N(μ,σ) respectively, having a correlation of ρ\rhoρ.

Idea: decompose YYY into a Z1Z_{1}Z1​ that it shares with XXX, plus an independent part Z2Z_{2}Z2​, with Z1,2Z_{1,2}Z1,2​ iid. N(0,1)N(0,1)N(0,1): X=sZ1+mY=c1Z1+c2Z2+μ\begin{align*} X &= sZ_{1}+m\\ Y &= c_{1} Z_{1} + c_{2}Z_{2} + \mu \end{align*}XY​=sZ1​+m=c1​Z1​+c2​Z2​+μ​The coefficient c1c_{1}c1​ of Z1Z_{1}Z1​ would control the correlation, and we adjust the coefficient c2c_{2}c2​ of Z2Z_{2}Z2​ to make sure the variance of YYY is correct.

  • Step 1: construct XXX with Z1Z_{1}Z1​.

To have X∼N(m,s),X\sim N(m,s),X∼N(m,s), we just choose Z1∼N(0,1), X=sZ1+mZ_{1}\sim N(0,1),\, X=sZ_{1}+mZ1​∼N(0,1),X=sZ1​+m.

  • Step 2: fit Z1Z_{1}Z1​ into YYY to get the correlation right.

Since Z1Z_{1}Z1​ independent from Z2Z_{2}Z2​ and μ\muμ, its coefficient c1c_{1}c1​ determines the correlation: corr(X,Y)=ρ=coeff(Z1)/σ\text{corr}(X,Y)=\rho=\text{coeff}(Z_{1}) / \sigmacorr(X,Y)=ρ=coeff(Z1​)/σso we can set c1=σρc_{1}=\sigma \rhoc1​=σρ.

  • Step 3: adjust the coefficient of Z2Z_{2}Z2​ to fix the variance of YYY.

Var(Y)=c12+c22\mathrm{Var}(Y)=c_{1}^{2}+c_{2}^{2}Var(Y)=c12​+c22​, so solving gives c2=σ1−ρ2c_{2}=\sigma \sqrt{ 1-\rho^{2} }c2​=σ1−ρ2​.
Since Z1,2Z_{1,2}Z1,2​ independent, adding this term does not change the correlation.

  • Plugging in the coefficients, X=sZ1+mY=σρZ1+σ1−ρ2Z2+μwhere Z1,2∼N(0,1) iid.\begin{align*} X&=sZ_{1}+m\\ Y&= \sigma \rho Z_{1}+ \sigma \sqrt{ 1-\rho^{2 }}Z_{2} + \mu &&\text{where } Z_{1,2} \sim N(0,1) \text{ iid.} \end{align*}XY​=sZ1​+m=σρZ1​+σ1−ρ2​Z2​+μ​​where Z1,2​∼N(0,1) iid.​has the desired correlations and variances.

  • To tie back to conditional distributions, writing YYY in terms of XXX gives the conditonal distribution of YYY given X=xX=xX=x.

Markov Chains

  • Consider a sequence of random variables (Xn)(X_{n})(Xn​) that takes values from a countable set III called the state space.
    • Usually the sequence is a change over time, e.g. the location of an elevator at time nnn, and the state space is the set of floors {0,1,2,…k}\{0,1,2,\dots k\}{0,1,2,…k}
    • In some cases it can use a more abstract sense of time, e.g. the nnnth character in an email, with state space {a,…,z}\{ a,\dots, z\}{a,…,z}.
  • If we treat III as a vector I=(I1,… )I=(I_{1},\dots)I=(I1​,…), the distribution of XnX_{n}Xn​ can be written as a row vector λ(t)\lambda(t)λ(t), where (λ(t))i=P(Xt=Ii)(\lambda (t))_{i}=\mathbb{P}(X_{t}=I_{i})(λ(t))i​=P(Xt​=Ii​).
    • In particular, X0∼λ0X_{0} \sim \lambda_{0}X0​∼λ0​ is the initial distribution.

Homogeneous Markov Chains

Big idea: homogenous Markov chains are memoriless random processes.

  • A sequence of random variables X=(X1,X2,… )X=(X_{1},X_{2},\dots)X=(X1​,X2​,…) all taking values in some state space III is called a Markov chain if for any k≥1k\ge 1k≥1, any states i0,…,iki_{0},\dots,i_{k}i0​,…,ik​: P(Xk=ik∣Xk−1=ik−1)=P(Xk=ik∣Xk−1=ik−1,…,X1=i1)\mathbb{P}(X_{k}=i_{k}|X_{k-1}=i_{k-1})= \mathbb{P}(X_{k}=i_{k}|X_{k-1}=i_{k-1},\dots,X_{1}=i_{1})P(Xk​=ik​∣Xk−1​=ik−1​)=P(Xk​=ik​∣Xk−1​=ik−1​,…,X1​=i1​)That is, the next state of the chain XkX_{k}Xk​ only depends on the present state Xk−1X_{k-1}Xk−1​, not the past.

  • A Markov chain is time-homogeneous if the transition probability P(Xk=j∣Xk−1=i)=pij\mathbb{P}(X_{k}=j|X_{k-1}=i)=p_{ij}P(Xk​=j∣Xk−1​=i)=pij​is constant, i.e. invariant of kkk. All chains in this course are homogeneous.

    • Hence transition probability pijp_{ij}pij​ is the probability of going from state iii to state jjj.

  • Homogeneous Markov chains satisfy the Markov property: for subsets A1,…m+n⊆I, i∈I,A_{1,\dots m+n}\subseteq I, \, i \in I,A1,…m+n​⊆I,i∈I,P(Xm+1∈Am+1,…,Xm+n∈Am+n∣Xm=i,Xm−1∈Am−1,…,X1∈A1)=P(Xm+1∈Am+1,…,Xm+n∈Am+n∣Xm=i)=P(X1∈A1,…,Xn∈An∣X0=i0)\begin{align*} \mathbb{P}(X_{m+1}\in A_{m+1},&\dots, X_{m+n}\in A_{m+n}|X_{m}=i, X_{m-1}\in A_{m-1},\dots, X_{1}\in A_{1})\\ \\ &=\mathbb{P}(X_{m+1}\in A_{m+1},\dots, X_{m+n}\in A_{m+n}|X_{m}=i) \\\\ &=\mathbb{P}(X_{1}\in A_{1},\dots, X_{n}\in A_{n}|X_{0}=i_{0}) \end{align*}P(Xm+1​∈Am+1​,​…,Xm+n​∈Am+n​∣Xm​=i,Xm−1​∈Am−1​,…,X1​∈A1​)=P(Xm+1​∈Am+1​,…,Xm+n​∈Am+n​∣Xm​=i)=P(X1​∈A1​,…,Xn​∈An​∣X0​=i0​)​

    • The first equality: Markov chains do not remember what happened before the present.
    • *The second equality: homogeneous Markov chains are translation-invariant.
  • A sufficient criterion for a Markov chain is that: a sequence of random variable Y=(Y0,… )Y=(Y_{0},\dots)Y=(Y0​,…) is a Markov chain if there exists a function fff and an sequence X=(X0,… )X=(X_{0},\dots)X=(X0​,…) such that: Yn+1=f(Yn,Xn+1), Xn+1 independent of Y1,…,nY_{n+1}=f(Y_{n},X_{n+1}),\, X_{n+1} \text{ independent of }Y_{1,\dots,n}Yn+1​=f(Yn​,Xn+1​),Xn+1​ independent of Y1,…,n​

N-Step Transition Probabilities

  • The nnn-step transition probability is defined to bepij(n)=P(Xn=j∣X0=i)p_{ij}^{(n)}=\mathbb{P}(X_{n}=j|X_{0}=i)pij(n)​=P(Xn​=j∣X0​=i)

  • For homogeneous chains, the transition matrix P∈R∣I∣2: Pi,j=pijP\in \mathbb{R}^{|I|^{2}}:\, P_{i,j}=p_{ij}P∈R∣I∣2:Pi,j​=pij​records the transition probabilities. The sequence XXX can be described as X∼Markov(λ0,P)X\sim \text{Markov}(\lambda_{0},P)X∼Markov(λ0​,P).

    • The matrix can be (countably) infinite if III is.

  • The Chapman-Kolmogorov equations describe n-step transitions with the transition matrix: for all homogeneous Markov chains, pij(n)=(Pn)ijpij(m+n)=(PmPn)ij=∑k∈Ipik(m)pkj(n)\begin{align*} p_{ij}^{(n)}&=(P^n)_{ij}\\ p_{ij}^{(m+n)}&=(P^mP^n)_{ij}=\sum_{k \in I} p_{ik}^{(m)} p_{kj}^{(n)} \end{align*}pij(n)​pij(m+n)​​=(Pn)ij​=(PmPn)ij​=k∈I∑​pik(m)​pkj(n)​​

    • The first equation: applying the transition matrix represents a 1-step move in time.
    • The second equation: the probability of going from iii to jjj in m+nm+nm+n steps can be broken down by conditioning on it passing kkk at the mmmth step.

Proof:
First equation: induction.
Second equation: immediate from the first, or use the law of total probabilities.

  • By the C-K equations, Markov chains can be represented by right-applying the transition matrix: for n≥m,n\ge m,n≥m,λ(n)=λ(m)Pn−m\lambda(n)=\lambda(m)P^{n-m}λ(n)=λ(m)Pn−m

Structures of Markov Chains

Class Structures

  • Two states i,ji,ji,j of a Markov chain communicate, denoted i↔ji\leftrightarrow ji↔j if: ∃m,n:pij(m)≠0, pji(n)≠0\exists m,n:p_{ij}^{(m)}\ne 0,\, p_{ji}^{(n)}\ne 0∃m,n:pij(m)​=0,pji(n)​=0

    • That is, there is a chance to go from iii to jjj, and vice versa.

  • As an equivalence relation, communication partitions the state space into communicating classes. A Markov chain is irreducible if it only has one communicating class.

  • A closed class CCC is a communicating class such that: ∀c∈C,d∉C,n∈N:  pcd(n)=0\forall c \in C, d \notin C, n\in \mathbb{N}:\, \,p_{cd}^{(n)}=0∀c∈C,d∈/C,n∈N:pcd(n)​=0It is also called an absorbing state if it has only one element.

    • That is, it is impossible to leave CCC once inside it.

  • An open class is a communicating class that is not closed.

Periodicity

  • The period of a state iii is gcd⁡{n:pii(n)>0}\gcd \big\{n:p_{ii}^{(n)}>0\big\}gcd{n:pii(n)​>0}and the state is aperiodic if its period is 111.

    • For example, a random walk of a length-nnn cycle has period 222 if nnn even; if nnn is odd, then the chain has period 111 hence is apeiodic.

  • The period is a class property: communicating states have the same period.

Proof: suppose i↔ji \leftrightarrow ji↔j, with m,n:pij(m)≠0, pji(n)≠0m,n: p_{ij}^{(m)}\ne 0,\, p_{ji}^{(n)}\ne 0m,n:pij(m)​=0,pji(n)​=0.
Define Si={k:pii(k)>0}S_{i}=\big\{k:p_{ii}^{(k)}>0\big\}Si​={k:pii(k)​>0}, similarly for SjS_{j}Sj​.
Then for any common divisor ddd of SiS_{i}Si​,
pii(m+n)≥pij(m)pji(n)>0⟹(m+n)∈Si,d∣(m+n) p_{ii}^{(m+n)}\ge p_{ij}^{(m)}p_{ji}^{(n)}>0 \Longrightarrow (m+n) \in S_{i}, d|(m+n)pii(m+n)​≥pij(m)​pji(n)​>0⟹(m+n)∈Si​,d∣(m+n)and for any a∈Sja \in S_{j}a∈Sj​, pii(m+a+n)≥pij(m)pjj(a)pji(n)>0⟹(m+n+a)∈Si,d∣(m+n+a)p_{ii}^{(m+a+n)}\ge p_{ij}^{(m)}p_{jj}^{(a)}p_{ji}^{(n)}>0\Longrightarrow (m+n+a) \in S_{i}, d|(m+n+a)pii(m+a+n)​≥pij(m)​pjj(a)​pji(n)​>0⟹(m+n+a)∈Si​,d∣(m+n+a) Hence d∣ad|ad∣a, ddd is also a divisor of the set SjS_{j}Sj​,
By symmetry, Si,SjS_{i}, S_{j}Si​,Sj​ have the same divisors, hence the same gcd\mathrm{gcd}gcd, and so states i,ji,ji,j have the same period.

Hitting Probability

  • The hitting probability of a subset A⊆IA \subseteq IA⊆I from state iii
    ishiA=P(Xn∈A for some n≥0 ∣ X0=i)h_{i}^A=\mathbb{P}(X_{n} \in A \text{ for some }n \ge 0 \,|\, X_{0}=i)hiA​=P(Xn​∈A for some n≥0∣X0​=i)
    and if AAA is closed, it is also called the absorption probability.

  • The hitting probabilities (i∈I:hiA)(i\in I:h_{i}^A)(i∈I:hiA​) of a Markov chain is the minimal non-negative solution to the equations hiA={1if i∈A∑j∈IpijhjAif i∉Ah_{i}^A=\begin{cases} 1 &\text{if }i\in A \\ \sum_{j\in I}p_{ij}h_{j}^A & \text{if } i\notin A \end{cases}hiA​={1∑j∈I​pij​hjA​​if i∈Aif i∈/A​where minimality means that (hiA)(h_{i}^A)(hiA​) is term-wise no larger than any other solution.

Proof: we can verify that (hiA)(h_{i}^A)(hiA​) satisfies the equations by conditioning on X0=i,X1=jX_{0}=i,X_{1}=jX0​=i,X1​=j.
To prove minimality, take any solution (xi)(x_{i})(xi​), and we shall show that ∀i∈I:xi≥hi\forall i \in I: x_{i}\ge h_{i}∀i∈I:xi​≥hi​.
Define the "probability of hitting before step NNN": qi(N)=P(∃n≤N:Xn∈A ∣ X0=i)q_{i}^{(N)}=\mathbb{P}(\exists n\le N: X_{n}\in A\,|\, X_{0}=i)qi(N)​=P(∃n≤N:Xn​∈A∣X0​=i)so qi(N)=∑jpijqj(N−1)q_{i}^{(N)}=\sum_{j}p_{ij}q_{j}^{(N-1)}qi(N)​=∑j​pij​qj(N−1)​, and induction on NNN gives ∀N,qi(N)≤xi\forall N, q_{i}^{(N)}\le x_{i}∀N,qi(N)​≤xi​.
Hence xi≥lim⁡N→∞qi(N)=P{⋃N{∃n≤N:Xn∈A ∣ X0=i}}=P{∃n:Xn∈A}=hiA\begin{align*} x_{i}\ge \lim_{ N \to \infty }q_{i}^{(N)}&=\mathbb{P}\Big\{\bigcup_{N}\{\exists n\le N: X_{n}\in A\,|\, X_{0}=i\} \Big\} \\&=\mathbb{P}\{\exists n: X_{n}\in A\}\\ &=h_{i}^{A} \end{align*}xi​≥N→∞lim​qi(N)​​=P{N⋃​{∃n≤N:Xn​∈A∣X0​=i}}=P{∃n:Xn​∈A}=hiA​​

Recurrence and Transience

Big idea: recurrence and transcience describes whether a Markov chain will indefinitely return to a particular state.

  • For convenience, we will denote the return probability as ri=P(∃n≥1:Xn=i ∣ X0=i)r_{i}=\mathbb{P}(\exists n\ge{1}: X_{n}=i\,|\, X_{0}=i)ri​=P(∃n≥1:Xn​=i∣X0​=i)but this notation is not standard.

  • A state i∈Ii\in Ii∈I is transient if ri<1r_{i}<1ri​<1, which means that P(the chain hits i infinitely many times ∣ X0=i)=lim⁡k→∞rik=0\mathbb{P}(\text{the chain hits } i \text{ infinitely many times}\,|\, X_0=i)=\lim_{ k \to \infty }r_{i}^k =0P(the chain hits i infinitely many times∣X0​=i)=k→∞lim​rik​=0

  • A state i∈Ii\in Ii∈I is recurrent if ri=1r_{i}=1ri​=1, which means that P(the chain hits i infinitely many times ∣ X0=i)=lim⁡k→∞rik=1\mathbb{P}(\text{the chain hits } i \text{ infinitely many times}\,|\, X_0=i)=\lim_{ k \to \infty }r_{i}^k =1P(the chain hits i infinitely many times∣X0​=i)=k→∞lim​rik​=1

  • A state iii is recurrent if and only if ∑n≥1pii(n)=∞\sum_{n\ge 1} p_{ii}^{(n)}=\infty∑n≥1​pii(n)​=∞.

Proof: the total number of hits has expectation ∑nE[1(Xn=i) ∣ X0=i]=∑nP(Xn=i ∣ X0=i)=∑npii(n)\sum_{n} \mathbb{E}[\mathbf{1}(X_{n}=i)\,|\, X_{0}=i]=\sum_{n}\mathbb{P}(X_{n}=i\,|\, X_{0}=i)=\sum_{n}p_{ii}^{(n)}n∑​E[1(Xn​=i)∣X0​=i]=n∑​P(Xn​=i∣X0​=i)=n∑​pii(n)​Then (the state is recurrent)   ⟺  \iff⟺ (the expected number of hits is infinite)   ⟺  \iff⟺ (the sum is infinite).

  • Recurrence/transience is a class property: states in the same communicating class are either all recurrent or all transient.
  • Recurrent classes are all closed; all finite, closed classes are recurrent.

The two propositions are proved in problem sheet 3.

Hitting and Return Times

  • The (first) hitting time of set A⊆IA \subseteq IA⊆I is the random variableHA=inf⁡{n≥0:Xn∈A}H^A=\inf\{n\ge 0: X_{n}\in A\}HA=inf{n≥0:Xn​∈A}
  • The mean hitting time of AAA from iii is kiA=E[HA ∣ X0=i]k_{i}^{A}=\mathbb{E}[H^{A}\,|\, X_{0}=i]kiA​=E[HA∣X0​=i]
  • The mean hitting times of the Markov chain (ki∈IA)(k_{i\in I}^A)(ki∈IA​) is the minimal non-negative solution to the equations kiA={0 if i∈A1+∑jpijkjA if i∉Ak_{i}^A=\begin{cases} 0 &\text{ if }i\in A \\ 1+\sum_{j}p_{ij}k_{j}^{A} & \text{ if } i\notin A \end{cases}kiA​={01+∑j​pij​kjA​​ if i∈A if i∈/A​

The proof uses the same strategy as the proof for hitting probabilities.

  • The mean return time of a state iii ismi=E[ inf⁡{n≥1:Xn=i} ∣ X0=i ]m_{i}=\mathbb{E}[\,\inf\{n\ge 1: X_{n}=i\}\,|\, X_{0}=i\,]mi​=E[inf{n≥1:Xn​=i}∣X0​=i]That is, the expected time to return to the state after starting from it.
  • A recurrent state with a finite mean return time is called positive recurrent; else it is null recurrent.
    • A transient state always has a mean return time of ∞\infty∞, since it has a positive probability of never returning.

Gambler’s Ruin as a Markov Chain

  • Model

Let the gambler’s wealth at time ttt be XtX_{t}Xt​, and the winning probability be ppp. They starts with $X_{0}=$ n$.
The transition probabilities are pij={p if j=i+1, i≠0q=1−p if j=i−1, i≠00 if otherwisep_{ij}=\begin{cases} p &\text{ if } j=i+1,\ i\ne 0 \\ q=1-p &\text{ if } j=i-1,\ i\ne 0 \\ 0 &\text{ if otherwise} \end{cases}pij​=⎩⎨⎧​pq=1−p0​ if j=i+1, i=0 if j=i−1, i=0 if otherwise​

  • Hitting probabilities

The probability of hitting zero starting from state iii, (hi)(h_{i})(hi​), comes from the equationsh0=1hi≠0=∑jpijhj=phi+1+qhi−1\begin{align*} h_{0}&=1 \\ h_{i\ne 0} &= \sum_{j}p_{ij}h_{j}=ph_{i+1}+qh_{i-1} \end{align*}h0​hi=0​​=1=j∑​pij​hj​=phi+1​+qhi−1​​which has the general solution hi=A+B(qp)ih_{i}=A+B\big( \frac{q}{p}\big)^ihi​=A+B(pq​)i, where h0=1h_{0}=1h0​=1 requires A+B=1A+B=1A+B=1.
Then non-negativity and minimality requires (A,B)={(1,0) if p≤q(0,1) if p>q(A,B)=\begin{cases} (1,0) &\text{ if }p\le q \\ (0,1) &\text{ if }p>q \\ \end{cases}(A,B)={(1,0)(0,1)​ if p≤q if p>q​So the hitting probability is 111 in the first case, and (q/p)i(q / p)^{i}(q/p)i in the second case.

  • Transience/Recurrence

The state 000 is obviously recurrent, since it is an absorbing state.

The rest of the chain communicate, so it is sufficient to find the transience/recurrence of the state 111. Its return probability is r1<p<1r_{1}<p<1r1​<p<1, so it is transient. Hence the entire class {1,2,… }\{1,2,\dots \}{1,2,…} is transient.

The lecture notes studies the modified chain where p01>0p_{01}>0p01​>0, which makes the chain irreducible, and we can find the return probability and mean return time to 000.

  • Mean hitting time of 000

If p>qp > qp>q, hitting probability is (q/p)i<1(q / p)^i<1(q/p)i<1, so the mean hitting time is infinite.

If p≤qp\le qp≤q, the mean hitting times (ki)(k_{i})(ki​) solve the equations k0=1ki≠0=1+∑jpijkj=1+pki+1+qki−1\begin{align*} k_{0}&=1 \\ k_{i\ne 0} &= 1+\sum_{j}p_{ij}k_{j}=1+pk_{i+1}+qk_{i-1} \end{align*}k0​ki=0​​=1=1+j∑​pij​kj​=1+pki+1​+qki−1​​The lecture notes involve some Olympic-level hand-waving to claim ki=βik_{i}=\beta iki​=βi, and the answer follows. To see why, note that ki=E[time to hit (i−1) from i]+ki−1=k1+ki−1\begin{align*} k_{i}&= \mathbb{E}[\text{time to hit }(i-1) \text{ from }i]+k_{i-1}\\ &= k_{1} +k_{i-1} \end{align*}ki​​=E[time to hit (i−1) from i]+ki−1​=k1​+ki−1​​by memorilessness. Then β=k1\beta=k_{1}β=k1​.

When p<qp<qp<q, solving gives ki=i/(q−p)k_{i}=i / (q-p)ki​=i/(q−p).

When p=qp=qp=q, any finite β=k1\beta=k_{1}β=k1​ failes, hence the mean hitting times (ki)(k_{i})(ki​) must be all be infinite.

Equilibrium and Convergence of Markov Chains

  • Recall that the distribution of the Markov chain variable XnX_{n}Xn​ can be expressed as a row vector λ(t)\lambda(t)λ(t), and right-applying the transition matrix PPP moves the distribution forward in time: for n≥m,n\ge m,n≥m,λ(n)=λ(m)Pn−m\lambda(n)=\lambda(m)P^{n-m}λ(n)=λ(m)Pn−mIn particular, if λ0\lambda_{0}λ0​ is the initial distribution, then Xn∼λ0PnX_{n} \sim\lambda_{0} P^nXn​∼λ0​Pn.
  • A distribution π\piπ is a stationary distribution of a Markov chain with transition matrix PPP if it is the left-eigenvector of PPP with eigenvalue 111: π=πP\pi=\pi Pπ=πPNote that it is the left-eigenvector, not the usual right-eigenvector.
    • That is, the transition matrix does not change the stationary distribution over time.

Convergence Theorems

  • Existence and uniqueness of the stationary distribution: if PPP is irreducible, then P positive-recurrent  ⟺  ∃!π stationary, where  πi=1miP \text{ positive-recurrent} \iff\exists!\pi \text{ stationary, where }\,\pi_{i}=\frac{1}{m_{i}}P positive-recurrent⟺∃!π stationary, where πi​=mi​1​where mim_{i}mi​ is the mean return time to state iii.

  • Convergence to the stationary distribution: if PPP is irreducible and aperiodic with stationary distribution π\piπ, any initial distribution has ∀i,j:\forall i,j:∀i,j: P(Xn=j)→πjpij(n)→πj\begin{align*} \mathbb{P}(X_{n}=j)\to \pi_{j}\\ p_{ij}^{(n)}\to \pi_{j} \end{align*}P(Xn​=j)→πj​pij(n)​→πj​​

    • Aperiodicity is important, as a periodic chain “remembers” its initial distribution.

  • Ergodic Theorem: for irreducible chains, the proportion of time spent on state iii converges to 1/mi1 / m_{i}1/mi​ almost surely: ∑t=0n−11(Xt=1)n→1mi a.s.\begin{align*} \frac{\sum_{t=0}^{n-1}\mathbb{1}_{(X_{t}=1)}}{n}\to \frac{1}{m_{i}} \text{ a.s.} \end{align*}n∑t=0n−1​1(Xt​=1)​​→mi​1​ a.s.​where for null-recurrent and transient states (mi=∞m_{i}=\inftymi​=∞), we interpret 1/mi1 / m_{i}1/mi​ to be 000.

Poisson Processes

  • A Poisson process models the occurance of events in continuous time; it is represented by NtN_{t}Nt​, the number of events that happened before time ttt.
  • The kkkth arrival time is Tk=inf⁡{t≥0:Nt≥k}T_{k}=\inf \{ t\ge 0:N_{t}\ge k \}Tk​=inf{t≥0:Nt​≥k}, and the kkkth interarrival time is Yk=Tk−Tk−1Y_{k}=T_{k}-T_{k-1}Yk​=Tk​−Tk−1​.
  • The rate of the process is a constant λ∈R\lambda\in \mathbb{R}λ∈R.
  • Poisson processes have two equivalent definitions. Each is useful for different problems.
    • The exponential interarrival time definition: a counting process is Poisson with rate λ\lambdaλ if its interarrival times are iid. Exp(λ)\text{Exp}(\lambda)Exp(λ).
    • The Poisson increment definition: a counting process NtN_{t}Nt​ is Poisson with rate λ\lambdaλ if:
      • Independence: increments over disjoint time intervals are independent.
      • Poisson: (Nt+d−Nt)∼Poisson(λd)(N_{t+d}-N_{t}) \sim\text{Poisson}(\lambda d)(Nt+d​−Nt​)∼Poisson(λd) for any ttt.

See the lecture notes for the proof of equivalence. It’s too long for me to bother summarizing it, and it’s probably not examinable.

Superposition and Thinning of Poisson Processes

  • Superposition: given two independent Poisson counting processes LtL_{t}Lt​ and MtM_{t}Mt​ with rates λ\lambdaλ and μ\muμ, their sum Nt=Lt+MtN_{t}=L_{t}+M_{t}Nt​=Lt​+Mt​ is also a Poisson process with rate (λ+μ)(\lambda+\mu)(λ+μ).
    • That is, poisson plus poisson is still poisson.

Proof: verify that NtN_{t}Nt​ satisfies the poisson increment definition of Poisson processes.

  • Thinning: given a Poisson process NtN_{t}Nt​ with rate λ\lambdaλ, if an occurance is not always counted, but only with probability ppp (independently), it still is a Poisson process with rate λp\lambda pλp.
    • That is, randomly sampled Poisson is still Poisson.

The lecture notes has a proof using the poisson increment definition, while the following is an alternative using the exponential interarrival time definition.

Proof: after the thinning, the interarrival time isY~=∑k=1NYk\tilde Y=\sum_{k={1}}^{N} Y_{k}Y~=k=1∑N​Yk​where N∼geo(p)N\sim \text{geo}(p)N∼geo(p).
Then MY~(t)=GR(MYk(t))M_{\tilde{Y}}(t)=G_{R}\big(M_{Y_{k}}(t)\big)MY~​(t)=GR​(MYk​​(t)) as shown in the “extra” theorem in the section Using Moment Generating Functions. We can then verify that Y~\tilde YY~ has the same mgf as Exp(pλ)\text{Exp}(p\lambda)Exp(pλ).
